Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.And yet…One night in the s, a young British student felt compelled to get up and pray for #Irina#. She had no idea who that was. A year later in London she met the Russian poet Irina Ratushinskaya, released from a labour camp in the USSR where she had been imprisoned for her Christian faith.Denied paper, she wrote poems on soap bars. In one poem she wrote:Believe me, it was often thus:I have never forgotten that extraordinary poem. How far can kindness reach In Mid Argyll there is a group of people who offer prayers for anyone who asks. You don#t have to be #religious# – whatever that means – to ask. You can ask for yourself or someone . It can be something huge, or something ordinary. It is totally confidential.People are sometimes touched that people they don#t know are thinking of them – a #sudden sense of joy and warmth, a resounding note of love#.Do ask. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.With the evenings getting longer and brighter, you can use your garden or patio as a great extension to your home, and just sit back and relax.It is at this time of year that lawns need to be mowed more frequently so here are some key pointers on getting that perfect cared-for look.Mow at least once a week and raise the mower blades when it is very hot weather.Don#t mow when grass is wet or during a drought and don#t collect your clippings during dry spells as this helps to conserve moisture.Keep watering throughout the summer unless there is a water shortage and repair bare patches with turf or re-seeding.This is also the month to ensure that all your plants are adequately fed, particularly those in baskets and tubs.Plants benefit from a regular feeding programme as they are growing vigorously and need their nutrition levels to be kept up.Slow-release granules are a good idea for pots and baskets because they last for about six months and release food as it is required into the compost.Not often thought of as a container plant, but an excellent option for small gardens, is a rose.A simple solution for June is to create an instant rose garden that you can enjoy throughout the summer.Just buy a selection of dferent sized pots, plant them with a ieties of roses and then place them together in a group.There is a rose for every garden situation. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.On May , you printed a letter from Ian Mitchell in which he claimed he did not receive any reply to an email he had sent me asking questions about Liberal Democrat policies.I replied to Mr Mitchell three hours and  minutes after receiving his email. Mr Mitchell acknowledged receipt of these answers.I was alarmed and saddened by the headline #Failing# school is #betraying# pupils and the community# in last week#s Courier.Coming from a retired Campbeltown Grammar Schoolteacher, it is hard to believe that someone who has worked in the profession could have such criticism for his her fellow colleagues.Although clearly passionate about the future of CGS, perhaps retirement has helped this inidual forget what a challenging job all school staff face.It is commonly known that CGS has not had its troubles to seek in recent years with major staff shortages due to ill health and other unforeseen circumstances.The league tables do not make good reading but, on their own, I don#t think they reflect the efforts of the staff.It is a well known fact that you can take a horse to water but you cannot make it drink. Is the behaviour of pupils the greatest barrier to success Despite the efforts of teachers to discipline the pupils, there are few deterrents for the offenders, especially where the pupil is aware that,they ask, the parent will fight their corner instead of backing the school.The responsibility of teaching our children to behave and respect others needs to be instilled from early years by us all and not just when the child reaches CGS.Maybe the retired teacher should offer his her skills and visit CGS and see the problems that all staff are facing It is time for the community to pull together and support our school and encourage our children to believe that a good education is very achievable in CGS.Recently, an investigation by the Herald newspaper uncovered that #just over half of Scotland#s leline ferry network is operating outwith its working le expectancy#, with  vessels out of  in operation over  years old.Despite the huge challenges created by the Covid- pandemic that our hard-working ferry crews have to deal with,  residents rightly expect a high quality ferry service that runs on time and has enough space to ensure they can travel to and from the islands, businesses can transport goods to the mainland and tourists can visit our islands to boost the economy.Unfortunately, cancellations and delays continue to plague routes. I have been working closely with residents, our community councils and other parties to find long-term solutions.This pressing matter simply can#t be left on the backburner.The  National Lottery Awards are now open for entries.Once again, the annual search for the UK#s favourite National Lottery-funded people and projects will recognise those iniduals and organisations who have made an extraordinary impact in their community – especially during these unprecedent times.National Lottery players raise £ million every week for good causes and we know this money is being used in amazing and inspiring ways.As part of The National Lottery Awards, we want to celebrate those whose selfless dedication and fantastic work makes such a dference in villages, towns and cities across the country.Encompassing all areas of National Lottery funding, you nominate local legends and hometown heroes in the following categories: culture, arts and film, community charity, heritage and sport.In addition, there will be a young hero award for someone under the age of .Groups or organisations are eligible to enter The National Lottery Project of the Year category, where shortlisted finalists will face a public vote later in the year.All award winners will receive an iconic National Lottery Awards trophy and £, for their organisation.Nominations can be made by completing an entry form on our website at www.lotterygoodcauses.org.uk awards.All nominees must have been funded by The National Lottery or be associated with a National Lottery funded project. Entries must be received by midnight on June .Now, as we approach summer with hopefully fewer restrictions, we can start to make plans about how we will spend time with family and friends.Following the challenging year we have experienced, we could all do with a bit more play in our lives. Play is a hugely important part of childhood and has a whole host of benefits, including improving physical and mental health and wellbeing.Throughout this pandemic, children have had to deal with so many dficult challenges some having to stay in unsafe homes and many living with families who are struggling with health worries and financial issues.Children have told Childline that they have struggled to cope and their mental health has suffered as a result.It doesn#t matter how people choose to play this Childhood Day , whether it#s organising a sponsored kickabout in the park, a game of cards, a musical get-together or an online gaming tournament, we just want as many as possible playing and raising money to help us keep children safe.We look forward to hearing how your readers plan to support the NSPCC and children across Scotland this Childhood Day.To find out more and download a fundraising pack, visit www.nspcc.org.uk childhoodday or search online for NSPCC Childhood Day.

In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.With one million copies of the DCI Daley series sold across all formats, Denzil is now reaching out with a new voice and in a new direction.Fans of the television shows The Sopranos and Gangs of London are likely to enjoy Meyrick#s new novel, Terms of Restitution, which will be published in hardback in September.While the DCI Daley novels are set in Kinloch, a fictional town based on Denzil#s native Campbeltown, Terms of Restitution is a completely new venture, revealing the darker side of human nature and taking readers to the dark streets of London and the Scottish town Paisley.Gangland boss Zander Finn is so sickened by the brutal murder of his son in a Paisley pub that he decides to change his le.Following the advice of his priest and mentor, he moves clandestinely to London and becomes an ambulance driver.But when his old second-in-command Malky Maloney tracks him down on a London street, Finn knows he must .Both his real family and his crime family face an existential threat from Albanian mobsters determined to take control of the Scottish underworld.Facing the forces of law and order under Detective Chief InspectorAmelia Langley and a mysterious Italian woman, Finn struggles for survival in a rollercoaster ride of brutality, tenderness, misplaced loyalties and the utterly unexpected.The path to redemption is a bumpy one, and it begins to look like Finn should have stayed in London.#I#m absolutely thrilled to bring readers something new,# said Denzil, now resident on Loch Lomondside. #I#m a huge fan of The Sopranos television show the mix of visceral crime, family le and bags of humour, I think, more accurately represents real le than unremittingly dark noir.#Thinking about that model, I#ve used my own approach in Terms of Restitution. Nobody lives a single-themed le, and I believe it#s really important,any authenticity is to be had, that characters inhabit as real and relatable a world as possible.#In Terms of Restitution, we see the stresses and strains of le on Zander Finn, as he struggles to come to terms with the pressure of his two families, his blood relatives, and his business family.#I#m also excited to unveil a new cast of characters, full of strong women like DCI Amelia Langley, and Maggie Finn, the formidable matriarch of both Zander#s families.#All told, I#m more than excited to let you spend time with the Finns in Terms of Restitution.#Is this a scintillating one-off  Or will it be the start of a new must-buy series  Denzil#s fans from Campbeltown to Canada will be thrilled to find out.And for those who can#t wait, his ninth DCI Daley novel, For Any Other Truth, will be published on June .

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: prestonpans-schoolboy-cycling-across-east-lothian-help-dads-project
story: Preston Tower Primary School pupil Aidan Stevenson will cycle a section of the John Muir Way from Dunbar Harbour to Fisherrow Harbour with dad Andrew to raise awareness for the Destiny Project.The youngster will travel  miles to support the registered mental health charity, founded by his father.Andrew Stevenson established the charity based on his own experiences with mental health as a teenager.The charity has a community engagement  called The Friends of the Destiny Project, which encourages East Lothian residents to support children and young people in the area.Andrew said: ldquoAidan has been training for his mammoth cycle with me and he wanted to encourage others to follow the Destiny Project mantra.ldquoIn preparation, Aidan has researched the meaning of mental health and the importance of raising awareness of it among children his age.Aidan and Andrew will set off from Dunbar Harbour at am on Saturday and aim to arrive at Fisherrow Harbour for pm.Aidan is seeking encouragement and support, and has asked locals to look out for him as he passes through the county, but stressed the importance of following Covid- guidelines.Aidan added: ldquoThank you to everyone who has supported me, I want to make other children happy by showing that you can achieve whatever you put your mind to.The father-and-son duo are hoping to raise pound, to deliver services in Wallyford, Whitecraig, Musselburgh, Prestonpans and Tranent.To sponsor Aidan, visit: gofund.me ccfe

South Scotland MSP Martin Whitfield has lodged the motion following Joshrsquos defeat of US fighter Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas on Saturday, meaning the Prestonpans man now holds all four belts in the super lightweight ision.Congratulating Josh on his latest success, Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThis latest victory has established Josh as one of the all-time greats of Scottish and British boxing."He has worked incredibly hard over the years to achieve this stunning level of success and thoroughly deserves all the plaudits he is receiving."He is an inspirational sporting figure and Irsquom sure that his achievements will encourage and inspire young people across Scotland and beyond to pursue their own sporting dreams.Mr Whitfieldrsquos full motion is as follows: "That the Parliament congratulates boxer Josh Taylor on his latest outstanding success in defeating US fighter Jose Ramirez with a unanimous points victory to become undisputed super lightweight champion of the world notes that, in so doing, he has become only the fth man, and the first British fighter, to claim the WBO, WBA, IBF and WBC titles simultaneously since the four-belt era officially began in , and that his victory also makes him the first Scot to be undisputed world champion since Ken Buchanan some  years ago believes that this achievement puts Josh firmly among the all-time greats of British boxing, as well as being an inspiration to young people in his home town of Prestonpans, East Lothian and across Scotland, and wishes him continued success with his formidable boxing career."

title: three-key-routes-focus-new-active-travel-consultation-musselburgh
story: The measures have evolved from the Musselburgh Active Travel Network Masterplan produced in .This identied six key active travel routes aimed at encouraging more people to get around the town without using a car.The masterplan, which resulted from previous consultation, received a ldquohigh level of support and further local connectors to the key routes have now been added to provide a complete network.The consultation will focus on outline design options for three key routes which run west to east, north of the town centre, and south to north from the new developments near Queen Margaret University and along the River Esk:Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoDue to current Covid restrictions, the initial consultation will be online and a specic project website has been created at musselburghactivetoun.infoldquoWe will also hold online discussions with stakeholders and community groups who the project team will contact over the next few weeks.ldquoWe hope to hold a number of events to engage with businesses, residents, community groups and schools as restrictions start to ease.ldquoDuring periods of lockdown, we know that many people have taken the opportunity to use methods of active travel more, with an increase in people choosing to walk or cycle more.ldquoFrom informal discussions, it appears that many local residents want to be able to continue to do so but in safer environments which we hope these key routes will provide.ldquoI would encourage people who live or work in Musselburgh to take the time to consider these proposals and to provide feedback that will help us shape the next stage. We want to ensure that the proposals make the best use of the street space.

title: musselburgh-couple-delighted-celebrate-diamond-wedding
story: John, from Fisherrow, known to his friends and colleagues as Ducky, worked in Bruntons Wiremill in Musselburgh, while June, from Gorgie, was a seamstress at Buchananrsquos in Edinburgh.They met at the dancing in the old Labour Hall which was situated above the police station on Musselburgh High Street.The week after, John, who entertains audiences by singing his favourite Scottish songs at parties and s, took June out on a date to the theatre to see Scottish singer Calum Kennedy.A fan of the works of Scotlandrsquos national poet Robert Burns, John, a past vice-president of the Newcraighall Poosie Nansie Burns Club, can recite the Bardrsquos works without looking at a book, much to the delight of his family, and is renowned for his talent in giving Address To A Haggis.Love blossomed for the couple and, after taking June on a date to the Wiremill centenary dance at the Stoneybank Institute, now the community centre, he asked her to marry him.Their wedding took place at Portobello Registry Office on May , , with Irene Dodds and George Hutchison as witnesses.The couple set up home at the Promenade in Musselburgh, where they lived until their family expanded, which saw them move to Galt Road ndash their home of  years.John worked with the electricity board based in Musselburgh for  years until he retired.He was an electrical fitter with ScottishPower, installing high-voltage switch gear in substations.June was a home help in the community for more than  years looking after the older generation.Prior to her retirement, she worked at Adamwood nursing home at Ravensheugh Road, Musselburgh.John, who is well known is fishing and shooting circles, also collected the football pools coupons for  years for Littlewoods pools.John, , and June, , have four children ndash John, Andrew, Kathleen and Margaret ndash  grandchildren and  great grandchildren.The couple enjoyed a low-key diamond wedding celebration at their Galt Road home amidst the Covid- pandemic, with family members attending at intervals to share a slice of cake and cup of tea.This is in contrast from their usual celebrations, which would always involve a large gathering of family and friends at a party with Scottish music and Johnrsquos favourite tipple, a wee dram of whisky.John and June were ldquoover the moon to receive a card from the Queen to mark the occasion, which was arranged by their daughters Kathleen and Margaret.The couple said that their recipe for a long and happy marriage was having ldquoa good close loving family around you, who love and care for you.June added that looking after John and all the dogs they had over the years gave her ldquomuch joy.

title: decision-plans-new-affordable-homes-dunbar-delayed
story: Members of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee were due to discuss the proposals on Tuesday last week.However, the fate of the plans on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road will now be discussed next Tuesday , after the applicants and their agents, Whiteadder Ltd and LBA, asked for a delay.The proposals are the third phase of development on the site, with  flats, immediately to the east, already in place.A further set of plans to transform the former manse on Bayswell Road, which was previously home to CrossReach ndash which offers care to people of all ages ndash into four apartments was also approved.The latest plans show  new properties spread across four three-storey buildings.Three of the flats would be one-bedroom properties, with the remaining  being two-bedroom properties.Dunbar Community Council had previously given its backing to the scheme, which was lodged with East Lothian Council in September last year.

title: musselburgh-lollipop-man-john-mclay-praised-one-kind
story: Popular John McLay, , who mans a crossing at Pinkie Road, near Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, goes the extra mile by wearing lsquocool characterrsquo socks and festive hats, turning into Santa at Christmas and buying a bunch of flowers each Friday to give to someone in the street in a bid to brighten up their day.Parent Kirsty Clark, who runs the after-school club, said: ldquoHe really is one of a kind, a truly caring and lovely man. He is always smiling even in the worst of weather. He takes the time to learn the childrenrsquos names and chats away to everyone.She explained that Mr McLay, of Goosegreen Avenue, Musselburgh, brings personal touches to the job like wearing ldquocool character socks that the children talk about all the way to school.At Christmas, he brings seasonal joy to everyone by wearing a dferent festive hat every day throughout December. He also grows a beard to play Santa at the after-school club but doesnrsquot fool the children, who know him so well.Mr McLay, who was brought up in Wallyford and has been a lollipop man for five years next month, said: ldquoIt is the best job Irsquove ever had.A sheet metal worker for Lothian Buses for  years, he took early retirement after caring for his late we, who was diagnosed with motor neurone disease.He said he was ldquoprivileged to work with the children and their parents.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore delighted to hear the positive comments about John and how appreciated he is by the families.ldquoOur crossing patrol guides provide a familiar and friendly face for children and families at either end of the school day. The guides are a much-valued part of the school community and we know that they enjoy the interaction they have with families too. Itrsquos lovely to see the Pinkie St Peterrsquos parents recognising this.One parent said: ldquoWe have recently moved but every morning my son insists on walking the long way so he can cross lsquoJohnrsquos roadrsquo.Another commented: ldquoMy twins are obsessed with John. It was one of the first names they were able to say.One said: ldquoMy kids just love him: the youngest is always so excited to see him and anytime we see him outside of the lsquolollipoprsquo role, he always takes the time to come and say hello.Another parent added: ldquoWersquove been here four years and he remembers each of the kidsrsquo birthdays. When my mum and dad visit from Fe, he always chats to my dad about the footie and,hersquos not seen them visit in a while, he will ask after them. Hersquos got a heart of gold.ldquoItrsquos not just in his job that hersquos so great, itrsquos outside in the community too, said another.ldquoHe saw us one night in Tesco looking a bit frazzled. As we were at the checkout, he came back with a bottle of Prosecco for me and said: lsquoHerersquos something to brighten your night.rsquo Too sweet!Another parent said: ldquoEvery Friday, John buys a bunch of flowers and gives them to a random person in the street in the hope it will brighten up their day.ldquoHe really is just such a genuinely nice person inside and out.The pupils also praised Mr McLay.Robbie said: ldquoJohn helps us to cross the road and makes me laugh, hersquos really funny.And Eli added: ldquoThe lollipop man is very fun and funny, he makes me smile in the morning.While Milo said: ldquoHersquos amazing and hersquos the best.Cathy added: ldquoJohn is cool and kind. I like his socks.

title: movies-returning-brunton-musselburgh-week
story: From Wednesday, the theatre will resume its big screen movies and event screenings in Venue , with modications to ensure comfort and safety in line with Scottish Government regulations. Staff will be on hand to welcome the public and answer questions.The film Nomadlandgets the programme going on Wednesday.The move is based on Jessica Bruderrsquos eponymous book, with a cast populated by real-le nomads playing fictional versions of themselves.From Oscar and BAFTA-winning director Chloe Zhao, this drama is a look at a rare way of le, full of quiet joy, generosity and humility, with a leading performance from the Oscar-winning Frances McDormand as Fern.Embarking on a journey through the American West, Fern stores all her worldly possessions and begins a simpler existence in her kitted-out van on the road. Recently widowed and having lost everything during the recession, her rugged, un-rooted lestyle baffles her friends and family as she drives from place to place on the lookout for seasonal work. Though Fern must adapt to the trials and pains of nomad le, she also finds a sense of community in the open road, the wizened, expansive landscapes and her dedicated compatriots.Then, Ammonitewill be screened on Wednesday, June .Set on the Dorset coastline, British filmmaker Francis Leeexplores the le of British palaeontologist Mary Anning in this period romance starring Kate Winslet and Saoirse Ronan.Anningrsquos talented but often overlooked career as a fossil hunter has left her walking the shorelines alone. When the melancholic Charlotte Murchison arrives, entrusted into Anningrsquos care by her wealthy husband, a compelling connection overcomes their initial fears. Marrying an unexpected friendship with overwhelming passion, the two women seek to overcome their great sense of loneliness.Minariis the midweek movie on Wednesday, June .In this semi-autobiographical family portrait from director Lee Issac Chung, a young Korean-American family move from Americarsquos West Coast to farm an isolated patch of land in Arkansas. On a mission to provide for his family, Jacobrsquosyearning for the American Dream conflicts with his fractured relationship with his we, his restless children and his own uncertain promises. A story of family devotion, migration and a sense of belonging in lsquos America, the arrival of the spirited, chaotic grandmother Soonjashts the family dynamic once more.Full information about all these events can be found at thebruntonTickets can be purchased directly through The Bruntonrsquos website or via the new box office number   , open Monday to Saturday, am to pm, until further notice.

title: looking-back-iconic-bass-rock-history
story: Baldred, the East Lothian saint, is said to have founded a hermitage on the island around  AD, and the ruins of St Baldredrsquos Chapel still stand.The Bass Rock passed into the ownership of the Lauder family, who built a castle on the island and kept sheep as a source of nourishment.King James I used the Bass as a prison for his political enemies.In , King James IV visited the Bass as a guest of Sir Robert Lauder, staying in his castle. James VI also came to the Bass in  as a guest of a later Lauder he liked the island so much that he offered to purchase it, but here he was snubbed.During the reign of Charles II, the Bass became a notorious prison, mainly used for the Covenanters.As many as  of these religious dissidents were held on the island, under appalling conditions: there was a well that produced fresh water, but fresh meat was a scarcity and the fishy taste of the seabirds was a torment to the wretched prisoners.In , four Jacobite officers were imprisoned on the Bass but they successfully took over control of the island and ordered the garrison to depart. After reinforcements had been received, they withstood a siege of nearly three years, under trying conditions, before they surrendered with full military honours in May .The Bass later passed into the ownership of the Dalrymple family, to which it still belongs today.The Bass Rock lighthouse was constructed in  by the celebrated engineer David Stevenson, a cousin of Robert Louis. He made sure that parts of the old castle were demolished for the stone to be harvested to build the -metre lighthouse, which served its purpose well for many years to come.It was lit with gas derived from vaporised paraffin oil for many years, monitored by the lighthouse keeper.Since , when the lighthouse was converted to electricity and remotely controlled, the lighthouse keeper was no longer needed, and the Bass Rock has been without any permanent human resident.From his house lsquoRockstowesrsquo on Melbourne Road, the celebrated postcard artist Reginald Phillimore enjoyed uninterrupted views of the Bass Rock.He had a fascination with the island, visited it many times and wrote a guidebook that he published himself.The Bass Rock is home to the largest gannet colony in the world: , birds spend their summer residence here, having been in Africa for the winter.The gannet, or lsquosolan goosersquo as it was known in Phillimorersquos time, is a large and formidable-looking seabird, with a white body, a yellow neck and head, and black and white speckled wings and tail.The reason that much of the Bass Rock appears white from a distance is the sheer number of birds and their acrid droppings.The gannet hunts fish by ing headlong into the sea, as any visitor to the Bass Rock can observe at close range.The air is full of birds, which are squawking cacophonously, and the smell from their droppings is very noticeable.Phillimore made some beautul postcards featuring the Bass Rock gannets he is likely to have travelled to the island from Canty Bay or on a vessel from North Berwick, but nowadays access to the Bass can be arranged via the Scottish Seabird Centre.This is an edited extract from Jan Bondesonrsquos book R.P. Phillimorersquos East Lothian

title: letter-week-climate-forest-must-done-right
story: While doing this, Irsquod like to encourage the council to apply the mantra lsquoRight trees, right place, right reasonrsquo, or these trees and their future growth are doomed.We have all seen the damage that mono-culture planting can do to landscapes and wildle. Trees for this Climate Forest need to be native species that enhance bioersity, planted where they can thrive, connect isolated pockets of wildle and benefit our local communities.They should also be planted in a way that improves peoplersquos enjoyment of their neighbourhood, while capturing carbon, reducing pollution and mitigating flooding.The council should lead by example and take full advantage of its own parks, playing fields, school grounds, open spaces and verges to create wildle corridors of trees and hedgerows, while building a network of green spaces for the people of East Lothian to enjoy.The golfing community could also play a major role in this project.East Lothian will also need to sign up new development to a  per cent tree cover and make developers plant at least one tree per garden space created.This, along with boundary hedges and native flowering areas, should help achieve the councilrsquos ambitious carbon targets.The proposed Climate Forest must also take into account local communities and their much-loved large mature trees currently in situ.The landscape of our county is changing, letrsquos make it for the better with the right trees, in the right space for the right reason.T ProudfootVictoria RoadNorth Berwick

title: special-hand-crafted-bench-finds-home-longniddry-dean-woods
story: The oak dowel and beech bench was designed and hand carved by path warden Graham Pettigrew.The bench was installed in the woodland area with the help of East Lothian Council Countryside Rangers.The intricate design of the bench represents the countryside from the Lammermuirs to the coast, and the spalted insets resemble the pattern of East Lothianrsquos shorelines.Wood carver Graham said: ldquoWhen visiting Loch Garten Nature Reserve, we were inspired by the design of a seat there which showed the landscape of Scottish pines on mountain slopes.ldquoI wanted to design and make a seat which was similarly fitting for our own local environment and seemed to grow out of it and feel part of it.Since retirement, Graham has carved items for enjoyment.He added: ldquoI designed the seat at the end of last year to be made from Scottish larch, sourced from Drem sawmills, and spalted beech which was found with permission after tree-felling in Gosford Estate.ldquoThe seat is held together by oak dowels and construction took around two months.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council is very proud of the work carried out by Graham Pettigrew in designing, making and installing the new bench, which was done in consultation with the Countryside Ranger Service.ldquoThe seat provides visitors to the Dean a place to rest for contemplation or just to enjoy the surrounding woodland and nature.Graham and his we Maxine are both path wardens for Longniddry Dean woods.Their hope is that the new seat will provide a place for reflection in a location that is often bathed in sunlight.One Facebook user said: ldquoThis is an absolutely stunning bench. I love walking through the Dean Woods, it is so relaxing ndash I will be heading there for a peek today.Another added: ldquoWhat a wonderful idea to have a bench there.

title: bridge-centre-haddington-preparing-reopen-groups-use
story: The Bridge Centre, which is used by organisations ranging from mother and toddler groups to the University of the Third Age, has been closed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Now, furloughed staff are ing with immediate effect to prepare the premises in line with Covid- secure measures.The first groups toto the centre, on Haddingtonrsquos Poldrate, will be priority groups that provide key or essential support to the community.More groups willthroughout May, with the aim, subject to any change in coronavirus restrictions, of being fully open for groups of all ages toto their activities by the start of the autumn term.Jenny Harper, chairwoman of the Lamp of Lothian, which owns the Bridge Centre ndash which was being used by up to , people a week before the pandemic ndash said that the buildings had been ldquoeerily quiet.She said: ldquoThe Lamp of Lothian Trust are delighted that the Bridge Centre and their activities will be reopening slowly but surely in the next few weeks and months, and I am fully aware of the caution and care the staff have been taking.ldquoThe buildings have been, like so many, eerily quiet, but that is not to say much has not been happening behind the scenes.ldquoThe Lammermuir Larder volunteers are offering a wonderful service to the community, as well as the Bridge Centre outreach team.ldquoWe have welcomed the Tyneside Tavern into the courtyard, opening when permitted and dovetailing with the Bridge Centre.ldquoHaddington House is fully let to local businesses and nearly all are ing to their inidual offices.ldquoThe Lamp continues to shine its light in the local community and we fully intend to extend our charitable operations as le s to normal this year.ldquoI would like to thank all our Friends of the Lamp and Trusts who have continued to support us, and to our tenants in Haddington House.ldquoThese incomes enable us to offer all the buildings at the Poldrate free, to the community and for the community.Although the Bridge Centre has been closed, the staff have not been idle.Online youth classes and music lessons have been taking place, while the community outreach team, along with the community wardens and police, have been out every weekend since June last year.Christmas and Easter appeals have been organised, while the Lammermuir Larder, which provides a local community food initiative set up to support people struggling financially, was established in February.The closure has also given the opportunity to see ldquomuch-needed maintenance carried out in the building.

title: iceland-costa-apply-signs-haddington-retail-park-moves-closer-opening

title: plans-bring-relay-life-event-dunbar-first-time
story: The Relay for Le event, which collects money for lesaving research, is set to be staged outside the townrsquos Hallhill Sports Centre next summer.A final date for the fundraiser, which would be coming to Dunbar for the first time, has not yet been confirmed but organisers are in early discussions with the representatives of the sports centre on Kellie Road.Carrie Lennon, Cancer Research UK relationship manager, is among those hoping to take part in the fundraiser, with the town close to her heart.Her uncle Greig Hannan , who was a talented musician and postman in Dunbar, was just  when he died in September  from kidney cancer.The dad-of-three, who played lead guitar in Setting Sons, a classic punk covers band, lived on the townrsquos Ash Grove and had also played football for Dunbar United and Cockburnspath FC.Carrie said: ldquoIrsquoll be lighting my own candle at Relay for Le Dunbar in memory of Greig and for other loved ones in my family who have been through cancer.ldquoWe are looking ahead to summer  with great hope and excitement.ldquoRelay for Le is an inspirational event.One of the most poignant parts of the Relay for Le event is the Candle of Hope ceremony, which take place as darkness falls and lights up the venue with dedicated candles, honouring every le touched by cancer.Candle bags are decorated and dedicated to loved ones lost to cancer, a friend or family member living with the disease, those who have survived, or hope for the future ndash a world where all cancers are cured.The ceremony is a chance for quiet remembrance, reflection and celebration.Carrie added: ldquoThe Candle of Hope ceremony is the only time that the relay stops as we come together as a community to honour everyone who has been affected by cancer, united in the belief that our fundraising is making a dference and that we will beat cancer.ldquoWersquod love for some more people to come forward to help shape and create this amazing event.ldquoDunbar, are you ready to relay During the relay event, team members take it in turns to walk around a track to show their solidarity in the fight to beat cancer, while a iety of stalls, games and music from performers provide entertainment.Members of the public interested in taking part in the event and raising funds for the charity are being invited to come forward.A new fundraising committee will be formed to make the East Lothian event a success.Every year, about#,#people are diagnosed with cancer in Scotland and one in two people#in the UK born after #will get cancer in their#letime.Cancer survival in the UK has doubled since the s and Cancer Research UKrsquos work has been at the heart of that progress.But more funds and supporters are needed.To find out more about how you can get involved in Relay for Le Dunbar, email Carrie.Lennon@cancer.org.uk

title: dunbar-schoolboy-parts-foot-hair-good-cause
story: Ansel Parkin has already unicycled and run his way to raising hundreds of pounds for East Lothian Foodbank and Comic Relief.Now, the Dunbar Primary School pupil has said goodbye to his long locks to boost the Little Princess Trust.Proud mum Kirsty told the Courier: ldquoHe is loving his new hair.ldquoSometimes he says that he misses his long hair but he really enjoys his new hair.ldquoHe has noticed his hair is growing exceptionally fast!The -year-old had been growing his hair for about two years ldquomostly because he could not decide on a haircut.His mum said that the youngster wanted to have it cut while in primary seven and also to mark the end of lockdown.On April , he made the trip to Jack and Ivy on Dunbar High Street for the change of style.Neighbour Aimee Muirhead was given the honour of chopping the Dunbar youngsterrsquos locks, which have been sent off to the Little Princess Trust.The charity provides real-hair wigs for youngsters who have lost their hair through cancer or due to other illnesses.A minimum of seven inches of hair is needed to make a wig, with donors urged to raise money and send their hair to the good cause.Kirsty, who lives in Dunbar with husband Dan and Anselrsquos brother Ebon, , said: ldquoAnselrsquos hair had become so long that it was actually at the end of lockdown that it seemed as good a time as any to mark it and do some fundraising.ldquoYou have to donate over six inches and his hair was probably I think about  centimetreslong and he had about  centimetrescut off.Ansel, who last spring unicycled  miles for East title: ross-high-rugby-club-delighted-newly-refurbished-gym
story: Found in the club on Blawearie Road, the new facility is currently open to adult players, who can take part in activities in line with the current coronavirus regulations and those set out by the Scottish Rugby Union.It is also hoped that, in future, youngsters from the townrsquos Recharge facility could have access to the gym.Ross Highrsquos players have not been able to fully train for seven months due to Covid rules, with restricted training taking place since April.Players have only now been able to resume regular training, the first time since November.Called the Chris Miller Fitness Suite after the clubrsquos long-time player and the projectrsquos major sponsor, the gym contains several weight benches, racks, weights, a bike machine, and two other weight machines.There is also a personal best board for players to mark and record their performance.A dumbbell rack will be the last piece of equipment installed, still to be purchased by the club.Almost all of the equipment was brand new, with the old second-hand pieces that used to be in place now no longer fit for purpose and not suitable for rugby.The gym, found near the changing facilities, is decorated in the clubrsquos colours.Work took place over seven months. The old gym was stripped bare, the walls painted, a new ventilation and sound system installed and new flooring put in.The club raised more than pound, in sponsorship from members, players, coaches and sponsors to help make the project a reality, while the Walk With Scott Foundation ndash whose founder, the late Scott Glynn, was the clubrsquos former president ndash and East Lothian Council also helped bring the gym to le.Due to Covid restrictions, players have to book a slot beforehand.Ryan Strachan, Ross Highrsquos rugby and business officer, said that with the season the club had had, the new gym was some good news.He added: ldquoA huge amount of work has gone into this project from initial fundraising, socially distanced work from a small group of volunteers and now organising safe re-opening for players using an online booking system.ldquoOn behalf of the club, a big thanks to our sponsors, contributors, the small group of highly committed volunteers and our suppliers.ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for membership and people wanting to help, we wouldnrsquot be able to do a lot of things.Younger players will be able to access the gym in due course in cooperation with Active Schools, while those who attend the townrsquos Recharge could also soon be able to use it.

title: new-colouring-book-east-lothian-reveals-rich-history
story: A History of East Lothian Colouring Book is a heartfelt tribute to the unique heritage of the county.The illustrations ndash based on the history of East Lothian ndash include the Roman Temple of Mithras at Musselburgh, the Siege of Haddington and detailed images of Scottish coastal industries.The book is being sold to raise funds for the Waggonway Project, which runs a heritage centre in Cockenzie celebrating the history of Scotlandrsquos first railway.Cockenziersquos Alan Braby, a founding member of the group and illustrator of the book, spoke about his new publication.He told the Courier: ldquoAs an archaeological illustrator living in East Lothian, the history, archaeology and local scenery is outstanding.ldquoIn my reconstruction drawings, I have always tried to include it all, from early prehistory to the unknown, but I have recently rediscovered events and incidents of the th and th centuries.ldquoFrom a large portfolio of images, we were able to select a few that gave a potted history of East Lothian that proved most suitable to this publication.The Waggonway Project was set up to protect and publicise the route of Scotlandrsquos first railway, the  Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway.Ed Bethune, Waggonway Project chairman, was delight with the bookrsquos launch.He said: ldquoAlanrsquos work has been a big part of the success of the Waggonway Project since  and we are delighted to celebrate this by bringing his fantastic artwork to a wider audience of all ages.ldquoThe book is greatyou want to add colour, or evenyou just want a collection of superb archaeological reconstruction to admire, and we are very grateful to Alan for his generosity in donating the proceeds to our community heritage projects.Alanrsquos book is available for purchase on the Waggonway website: waggonway product-page alan-braby-s-east-lothian-colouring-book

title: refurbishment-alterations-planned-cockenzie-primary-school
story: East Lothian Council is seeking permission to make alterations, including the demolition of a redundant chimney, at Cockenzie Primary School.The planning application, which is being considered by the local authorityrsquos planning department, outlines the work proposed.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council anticipated that the work could be carried out during the school holidays.She said: ldquoSubject to planning approval, work will be carried out at Cockenzie Primary School over the summer holidays involving major external refurbishment.ldquoThis includes flat roofing works, rooflight and window replacement, installation of an external insulated render system and the demolition of a redundant chimney.ldquoIn addition, internal works include an electrical rewire, new lighting and suspended ceilings to be undertaken to five classrooms.ldquoThis is part of a rolling programme of primary school project works and maintenance.

title: new-owners-taking-drummohr-caravan-park
story: International real estate advisor Savills, on behalf of private clients, has completed the sale of Drummohr at Levenhall, Musselburgh, to employee-owned leisure, retail and distribution specialist WCF Ltd for an undisclosed amount.Jo Ritzema, managing director of WCF Ltd, said this was the companyrsquos first caravan, camping and glamping site in Scotland, with the nearest being a five-star facility at Herding Hill Farm near Hadrianrsquos Wall in Northumberland.She stressed that the company hoped to go on to increase its portfolio of camping and glamping sites in southern Scotland and the north of England.The site is developed to accommodate  luxury holiday letting lodges, seven of which have hot tubs,  touring caravans, tents and motorhomes, together with  glamping units.The site also includes a storage area for up to  touring caravans, a three-bedroom bungalow with hot tub, two amenity blocks and a shop.The .-acresite is situated in the formerly walled gardens of a monastery and was converted to a holiday park in . It has been owned and run by the same family since .Mrs Ritzema first visited Drummohr as a camper herself, saying it benefited from the draw of Edinburgh and the ldquobeautul coastline and countryside of East Lothian.She said that the company, which has its registered office at Brampton, near Carlisle, had started an external refurbishment programme at Drummohr involving painting and decorating, with further plans to ldquoupdate and upgrade the facilities such as lodges and glamping units.She said that the site had a large touring area for tents and caravans which would also be improved, with the amenity blocks, accommodating showers, toilets and laundry, refurbished. It was also planned to add an indoor area including a kitchen for campers.Mrs Ritzema added that, given the ldquosignicant growth in glamping, additional units would be provided subject to consultation and the necessary planning consents.She added that the seven staff members, one of them part-time, who worked at the site had been retained, with a recruitment process under way for a further three or four new employees.They either live on-site or in the local area, including Angie Purves, an East Lothian resident who has been promoted from office manager to take over the running of Drummohr.Mrs Ritzema said that everyone involved in the venture was ldquomadly excited by it all and added that a new website for the site would highlight local visitor attractions.Richard Prestwich, director in the leisure and trade team at Savills, said: ldquoHoliday parks have become exceptionally sought-after due to the growing trend for staycations. It is encouraging to witness new entrants, such as WCF, targeting the holiday parks market and competing with the existing multi-park owners that have traditionally dominated the marketplace.

title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: picture-gallery-duke-duchess-cambridge-visit-heavy-sound-cockenzie
story: William and Catherine, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, were in Cockenzie yesterday as part of their ongoing tour of Scotland.The couple were visiting Heavy Sound, which works with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit , a joint project backed by the police and the Scottish Government which tries to tackle the root causes of violence.During the visit, the Duke and Duchess saw young people doing martial arts, music production and bicycle maintenance, organised by community organisation Heavy Sound, which is based at the Cockenzie Hub on Edinburgh Road.Manager Thilo Pfander persuaded Kate to try her hand at making some EDMand at first the Duchess received some encouragement from her husband, who said: "Yeah, drop a beat in the background."Kate did produce a bass-heavy track but added a piercing synth sound over the top.William laughed and said: "Whats that "It sounded like a cat... It might catch on ndash in about a hundred years time!"After a few moments, William pleaded for it to stop,saying: "Its hurting my ears."He then added: "Im not sure its number one material yet."

title: spectators-welcomed-musselburgh-racecourse-afternoon
story: The East Lothian track will admit  pre-booked race spectators at noon todayin the first step towards resuming normal racing.The racecourse worked carefully with East Lothian Councils Safety Advisory Group to establish a raceday protocol ahead of the event.Alcohol and food can only be ordered but must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.Musselburgh Racecourse said in a post on Facebook today: ldquoThe track is in great condition today. Were thrilled to welcome back spectators for the first time since February !The sold-out event will host eight races, with the first beginning at .pm.The next spectator event at the Musselburgh track is The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June .Musselburghs popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to August  to give spectators the best chance of relaxed Covid- rules.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: national-lottery-scrapped-newsagents-new-licence
story: Newsagents are worried a new operator would want to accelerate online and app sales which could prove disastrous for local convenience stores.The Gambling Commission is set to announce whether Camelot will keep hold of the licence for a fourth term in the next six months.And according to The Grocer, nearly half of convenience retailerssay the National Lottery is more important to their business than ever.Sisal, Allwyn, Sugal  Damani and Camelot are currently in contention for the new licence, with Richard Bransonrsquos Virgin Group and Northern  Shell other companies rumoured to be applying., retailers across the UK currently work with Camelot, earning around % commission on each draw-based game.Jason Birks, deputy VP at the National Federation of Retail Newsagents , said: ldquoCurrently, the National Lottery does have an online presence but Irsquove heard that some of the bidders want to do a lot more online and from a high street point of view, and from the point of view of community-based retailing, we need to protect bricks and mortar.ldquoThose in government need to not only view online as the lsquotrendyrsquo thing to do but bear in mind that people still like to visit bricks and mortar retailing.One independent retailer told The Grocer: ldquoI donrsquot think Camelot deserve another licence as for the last few years they have been very average with limited innovation, mediocre support for retailers with too much red tape.ldquoA new licensee should create a fresh approach and more energy.A Camelot spokesperson said National Lottery retailers earned around pound, in commission on average in  .A statement read: "We fundamentally believe that The National Lotterys success ndash which culminated in record sales last year ndash is reliant on building and maintaining a healthy retail channel."Thats why weve invested heavily in retail at the same time as growing the largest digital lottery channel in the world by revenuehellip"While were unable to share specic details of our bid, we can say that Camelots philosophy remains the same ndash with retail being a cornerstone of our strategy. National Lottery retailers have been fantastic partners to us over the past  years and, as theyve always been there for us, they can expect our continued support."

title: heros-welcome-josh-taylor-boxer-arrives-home-prestonpans
story: Proud residents gathered outside the Prestoungrange Gothenburg to welcome home their own Tartan Tornado after he beat his American rival Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas this weekend.Josh was crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the world on Saturday after a stunning unanimous points victory.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the worldDedicated fans braved the cold and rain to catch a glimpse of the world champion as he arrived home.Josh, accompanied by his fianceacutee Danielle Murphy, slowed his car to soak in the adulation of the crowd that had gathered outside his local pub.One of the first to greet the heroic boxer was his dad, James .Diane Taylor, Joshs mum, said she was overwhelmed seeing her son again as he ed home from his history-making win.She added: "I feel absolutely amazing."The energy of him driving through was amazing because I was panicking there wasnt going to be anybody here because of a mix-up with the flights and everything, but when I saw everybody I was so pleased, it is brilliant."The crowd erupted into cheers and chants as the champion drove down High Street at pm.Lara Connerton and Kenny Ainslie came out to celebrate Joshs arrivalOne resident, Lara Connerton, said: "I am super proud, it is absolutely amazing."He stopped and spoke to everyone and he took photos with the children in the streets."He is absolutely lovely, a top guy.""We are going to go and have a pint to celebrate."Another, Kenny Ainslie, said: "Its lovely seeing him, we are so proud."The Courier was live from Prestonpans when Josh arrived ndash watch a short video of his arrival here.

title: heading
story: Carrie Williamson was with her son and daughter, Finlay and Bonnie Loftus, aged seven and five, and their bulldog Mable, when they saw the stone propped up against a fence by Prestoungrange Mining Museum, Prestonpans.Read More: Heros welcome for Josh Taylor as he arrives home in PrestonpansJosh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival Jose Ramirez with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion in Las Vegas on Saturday."The children were super excited to find it especially when they realised it was specially made for a world champion," said Carrie.The family, who live at Pinkie Braes, took a quick photo of the stone and put it back in its place for others to find and enjoy.Read More: Josh Taylors fiancee excited to plan wedding to the heroJosh, who ed to Scotland yesterday, was greeted with a herorsquos welcome as he passed through Prestonpans at pm.Supporters gathered outside the Prestongrange Gothenburg to cheer for the titleholder as he slowed his car to soak in the elated crowds.Read More: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed champion of the worldFans waved Scottish flags and signs on the High Street as Josh headed home to Haddington for some well-deserved rest.One sign read: lsquoHaud yir wheest Ramiz, your belts are coming tae the Pans.rsquoResidents from Northbank Road, Prestonpans, huddled together amid the cold on Saturday night to watch Joshrsquos fight on a projector.A banner on the street said: ldquoThis is my hometown, the place I was born in, no matter where I go itrsquos in my soul.ldquoMy feet may wander a thousand places, but my heart will lead me back home to Prestonpans.

title: lone-swan-finds-new-love-river-esk-musselburgh
story: Bonnie was taken to a new home on the River Esk when she abandoned her nest at Figgate Park, Portobello, after losing her partner Clyde.It appeared he had been in a fight with another male swanand had to be put to sleep.Sarah Auldsmith, Scottish SPCA senior animal rescue officer, said: ldquoWe were contacted back in April about an injured swan at Figgate Park.ldquoIt appeared a resident male swan, Clyde, had been in a fight with another male, resulting in a leg injury that made him unable to walk.ldquoClyde had also had bad arthritis for a number of years, which had been slowly getting worse.ldquoThis, coupled with him now being completely unable to stand, meant that he would not recover and the dficult decision was made to put him to sleep to end his suffering.She explained that Bonnie abandoned her nest about a month after losing Clyde.ldquoShe had been doing her best to incubate them but without her partner, and with her constantly being attacked by the new male, the eggs were unfortunately not viable, said Sarah.ldquoBonnie was moved to Musselburgh a couple of weeks ago and seems to be getting on well in her new environment.ldquoWe havenrsquot heardshersquos found a new mate yet but this is certainly a possibility as swans will often take up with another partner after their previous one has passed away.ldquoWhen she moved, Bonnie left her eggs in the nest and they have most likely been predated on since then.Photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, captured Bonnie on camera enjoying her new le on the Esk and it is thought she may have even have found love again, after being snapped with a new admirer.Mr Bathgate said that during a visit to the Esk, he was told by someone who was involved with the welfare of the swans that Bonnie could be singled out by the identication number on her tag.He added: ldquoIt made my day when Bonnie and her new mate chose to show their bonding together, which I captured on camera.Sarah appealed to the public: ldquoIf you discover any injured wildle, please contact our helpline on   .

title: heavy-sound-founder-says-dad-joke-duke-duchess-cambridge-bombed-visit
story: Jordan Butler met the royal couple at its premises in Cockenzie Business Hub as they learned about Heavy Soundrsquos work and its partnership with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit .The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during their visit. All images: Andy Buchanan PA WireArriving at .pm, the couple, known as the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when in Scotland, squeezed a lot into their hour-and--minute visit.Heavy Sound, which moved from Tranent to Cockenzie last July, was the only place the couple visited in the hub in what is thought to be their first official visit to East Lothian.The Duchess tried mixing a dance music track alongside Jordan and music services manager Thilo Pfander but received a scathing review from her husband.: Picture gallery of Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visiting Heavy Sound in CockenzieDespite her insisting the track be deleted, Jordan said it had been saved and was waiting to hear what he could do with it, joking of a pending release.He added that the track was not as bad as the Duke made out and he enjoyed listening to it.But his ldquodad joke to the duo of getting royalties from the song should it be released did not go down as well as he thought it would, he recalled.William and Catherine also visited Heavy Soundrsquos community reach and inclusion bus , which is kitted out with recording equipment, IT and office equipment, a kitchen and hairdressing space.Jordan said the royals took a great interest in the project, discussed how it came about and the work it does.He added: ldquoOn board the bus they had a big interest in mental health.ldquoThey also had in-depth knowledge of childhood trauma and work with early years it is obviously something they know about and have a lot of knowledge in.Heavy Sound partners with vulnerable, disadvantaged and disengaged young people using music and sport.About  per cent of the young people have care experience and or complex childhood trauma. It works with  young people and  adults.Heavy Sound is in partnership with the SVRU, which helped make the CRIB possible alongside support from the Scottish Prison Service and STV Childrenrsquos Appeal.During the pandemic, the CRIB became an lsquoalternative classroomrsquo, offering a safe place for the children of key workers and vulnerable children. It also distributed , lunches during the first lockdown and , in the second.The royal couple also watched the Thai boxing group and mixed martial arts programme lsquoFight Like A Girlrsquo."We tried our best to get them [the royal couple] involved in Thai boxing and hitting some of the pads but they were more interested in speaking to the young people, said Jordan.ldquoKate did go on the mat with her high heels on, which is a big no-no, but you can make exceptions for certain people!William declined the invitation, saying he did not have the right equipment but that he used to box during his time in the army.Heavy Sound also works on mentoring and building skills and development, with William and Catherine also visiting Heavy Soundrsquos bike maintenance facility.The visit meant a lot to Jordan, who was homeless himself from the age of  to  and suffered with substance misuse as a result. Music was how he expressed himself, which is one reason why Heavy Sound has such a focus on it and ldquobuilding relationships and more alternative and positive forms of expression.He added: ldquoWe are able to offer our young people as many opportunities for positive engagement as possible and show them that through building relationships and engaging, they can get opportunities.Jordan told the story of one girl who suffers from social anxiety ndash she not only made it through the door on the day of the visit but spoke to the royal couple and showed off her artwork in an experience that Jordan said ldquowill stay with her for the rest of her le.On the Duke and Duchess, he said: ldquoThey are lovely and really down to earth. I felt incredibly relaxed."But it was so surreal at the same time. It did become normal pretty quickly, though.

title: newhailes-house-musselburgh-reopens-brand-new-visitor-attractions
story: The Palladian Villa, which boasts original furnishings and possessions from more than  years of inhabitants, has reopened with brand new visitor attractions.The National Trust for Scotland property has undergone restoration work to welcome visitors again after a sprinkler system mal and a moth infestation saw it close in February .The conservation charity has introduced a brand new visitor experience inside the house, with catering facilities available on the estate.Visitors can enjoy Weehailes Playpark and a new takeaway ice cream parlour and coffee shop, The Dairy.The dairy premises once provided milk, cream and butter for all those who lived and worked on the estate.The team at Newhailes has developed three new visitor tours, one of which can now be pre-booked at www.nts.org.ukThe first tour explores the last  years of le at Newhailes and the trustrsquos role in saving the house and estate.The second tour sheds further light on the property, telling the tales behind the art collections and objects in the house.The final tour is targeted at families and explores the home through storytelling it is suitable for those with young children.Claire Grant, operations manager for Edinburgh, said: ldquoWersquove been taking steps to revitalise Newhailes since before  and plans were further delayed when the pandemic hit.ldquoWe wanted to create a new experience that the local community could enjoy, in addition to offering a good-quality food and drinks experience.ldquoWersquore really excited to be welcoming visitors back to Newhailes House after what has been a very long period of closure and we hope they enjoy some of our new additions, like our Dairy and Stables Cafe.ldquoSo many people love this place, and we are really pleased to be able to welcome visitors from near and far back once again.ldquoAll of our properties across Edinburgh and the Lothians have been making visits as safe as possible."Pre-booking is in place at a few sites and there are smaller groups for house tours."She said that visitors should book their slot at Newhailes in advance to avoid any disappointment.Newhailes House is open to the public for tours from Wednesday to Sunday.For more information on safety measures in place, visit nts.org.uk stories what-to-expect-when-visiting-our-places

title: hopes-open-top-bus-parade-plans-considered-best-way-celebrate-josh-taylors-win-prestonpans
story: Danielle Murphy, Joshrsquos fianceacutee, said she was looking to put plans in place for an open-top bus parade, so her partner could show off his prized championship belts to his fans, but is awaiting confirmation from East Lothian Council.: Josh Taylors fianceacutee ecstatic about his win - and excited to start wedding planningMeanwhile, Prestonpans Community Council meets on June  to discuss commemorating Joshrsquos success, but has said that any celebrations will follow coronavirus restrictions.Brian Weddell, community council chairman, said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted for Josh and his family after his win ndash given he is Prestonpans born and bred, this is an amazing achievement for East Lothian.ldquoHe is a credit to Prestonpans.: Josh Taylor receives heros welcome onto PrestonpansGraeme Hutchison, Prestonpans Gala Day convenor and secretary, said that early discussions with partnering agencies had begun to plan a local celebration for Joshrsquos historic win.He added that there should be an official event to allow Josh to parade through the town and community members to see him and his championship belts.Mr Hutchison said that the gala committee were eager to finalise plans to celebrate the -year-oldrsquos success on behalf of the town and community.Residents have also called for Josh to be suitably honoured for his achievements, including suggestions that he should be knighted.One Facebook user said: ldquoJosh should be getting a knighthood for what he has achieved ndash the same as Chris Hoy, Andy Murray and Lewis Hamilton did in their sporting achievements.Another said: ldquoHe should be greeted by the First Minister and given the freedom of the cities of Scotland!When askedEast Lothian Council had any plans for commemorating Joshrsquos success, a council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are delighted for Josh and his family on this historic achievement and are actively considering the most appropriate way to recognise it.John McMillan, East Lothianrsquos Provost, also congratulated Josh.
