title: uk-australia-trade-deal-likened-highland-clearances-snp-accused-isolationism
story: Kenny MacAskill challenged Greg Hands, UK trade minister, over the plans in the Commons this afternoon, saying the Tories ldquodonrsquot even care about Scottish sheep let alone crofters and farmers.The trade deal has raised concerns with farmers across the UK, who are worried that cheap imports of beef and lamb could see the demand for their home-grown produce dwindle.Others say they are worried about inferior products, such as hormone-injected beef coming to the UKs supermarkets - a claim the Government denies and says hormone-injected beef would never be allowed to be imported to the country.Mr MacAskill, Alba MP for East Lothian said: ldquoOver  years ago the Highland Clearances saw people shamefully replaced by sheep for landlord profits.ldquoNow this trade deal threatens to supplant those sheep with cheap imports for Tory dogma.Mr Hands replied that the production costs in the Asian markets were ldquotwice what they are in the UK adding: ldquo[This] makes it very competitive for Australia to sell into for example, markets like Japan, markets like Korea, where the domestic production price of beef is twice that in the UK.He added that the Australian lamb quota into the UK was ldquonot even fully used at the moment.Drew Hendry, the SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, cited warnings from the National Farmersrsquo UnionScotland and England, saying they would struggle to competetarf-free access was granted to Australian beef and lamb exporters.Mr Hendry said the government was ldquosimply not listening to those at the sharp end and quoted NFU Scotland president Martin Kennedy, who said: ldquoOur seafood industry has already been hit hard by Brexit and now Scottish farming is next to be sacriced. Once again its Scotlands key industries which will bear the brunt of a Tory Brexit people here didnt vote for.Mr Hendry continued: ldquoNFU England warned ministers that they would struggle to compete of zero-tarfs trade on lamb or beef went ahead and the RSPCA have warned that tarf free access for Australia would betray the public, farmers, and the animals. These are just some of the warnings to government from those affected, not from politicians.ldquoWill the minister rule out tarf-free access for Australian agricultural produce However Mr Hands hit back, accusing the SNP of being ldquoisolationist and said Mr Hendry had ldquoserious questions to answer.He said: ldquoNever in  years has the SNP supported any trade deal done by either the UK, or even by the EU, even though key sectors of the Scottish economy like whiskey, like apparel, like fisheries, are dependent on trade.ldquoThey voted for no-deal Brexit, they voted against deals with our friends like Canada, Korea and South Africa. They didnt support deals with Japan or Singapore.ldquoI dont think that whatever assurances I have given you today or whatever turns out to actually be in the deal would make him and the SNP support this deal.ldquoWhen it comes to trade Mr Speaker, the SNP are isolationist and against the best interests of Scotland. ldquoPatricia Gibson, SNP MP also challenged Mr Hands, asking him why farmers could not understand ldquohow fabulous the UKrsquos deal was and adding: ldquoCould it be the case that this government is being disingenuous about the impact this deal will have on your farmers The minister said that Scotland would ldquobenefit from this deal very strongly overall.

title: crackdown-long-stay-parking-three-car-parks-among-new-waiting-restrictions-introduced
story: A meeting of the councilrsquos cabinet this week approved plans to limit waiting times at two Tranent car parks and one in Dunbar to just  minutes.The minority Labour administration was told that a car park on Abbeylands in Dunbar had been ldquoconstructed to assist with visitors accessing and utilising the High Street businesses however, it ldquois being used primarily as a long stay.They were asked to approve a bid to introduce a -minute waiting restriction at the car park, as well as Lindores car park in Tranent, which currently has a temporary restriction under the Safer Spaces project, and a section of car park across from Tranent Medical Practice.Councillors were told that patients had complained about being unable to park for appointments because it was always full.They were also asked to approve extending waiting restrictions to streets across the county which were becoming jammed by ldquoindiscriminate parking, as well as extending a one-way system at Musselburghrsquos Harbour Road to adjoining Lochend Road North.Additional speed restrictions are also being applied for under Traffic Regulation Ordersin West Barns, as well as a bid to stop up part of South Street in Belhaven and section of Newton Port, Haddington.The cabinet also approved a bid to introduce  new electric vehicle chargers at locations across the county, including  at Wallyfordrsquos park and ride facility.Following the approval of the plans to apply for new and amended TROs, Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet member for environment, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has a responsibility to ensure local towns and villages have safe, accessible routes of travel that recognise the needs of a range of road users, pedestrians and businesses.ldquoAs the county develops and travel patterns change, the council can be approached by local communities concerned about a range of travel-related issues.ldquoThe new and amended TROs approved were identied as necessary to improve or enhance the free movement of traffic whilst also supporting other road users.ldquoThe council is committed to creating greater opportunities for active travel which can benefit inidual wellbeing and energise our town centres.A full list of the TROs applied for can be found at https:www.eastlothian.gov.uk meetings meeting  cabinet

title: plans-lodged-crematorium-near-musselburgh
story: East Lothian Council will now consider the project from the Westerleigh Group, a developer and operator of crematoria and cemeteries, with  facilities in England, Scotland and Wales.A single-storey crematorium, of around m internally, which would house a -seat chapel, is planned in the larger of two fields on the site.There would be a waiting room, accessible toilets, administration office, crematory, covered walkway and floral tribute area.Car parking providing  spaces, including six disabled accessible bays and an additional four spaces for staff parking, and memorial gardens are also planned.George Bell, regional manager for north and east from Westerleigh Group, said: "There is a pressing need for a crematorium in East Lothian."East Lothian does not have a crematorium of their own and their residents currently have to travel long journeys into Edinburgh, through busy roads, to access a crematorium."The area already has a large population base and this is going to grow further in the coming years, with some signicant new housing developments being planned."If our planning application is successful, this new crematorium will also serve the wider Edinburgh City region."We pride ourselves on creating and maintaining crematoria which are welcoming, attractive places for remembrance and reflection, and which are true assets to their local communities."The teams at all our crematoria have proudly earned a reputation for providing exceptional care and support to local people, enabling families to remember, mourn and celebrate the lives of their loved ones in a way that is uniquely personal, and we look forward to hopefully being able to bring that same high level of service to the people of East Lothian."Earlier this year, we conducted a public consultation exercise and were delighted to receive a positive response."The full planning application has now been submitted and we hope to receive a decision in early autumn."The site of the proposed development is around  acres, located north of the village of Old Craighall. It is located to the south of the slip road linking the eastbound A to the westbound A and these form the northern and eastern boundaries of the new crematorium. The western boundary is formed by Old Craighall Road and the southern boundary is formed by a minor road linking Old Craighall Road with the eastern part of Dalkeith Country Park.A planning statement, issued on behalf of the company by Holder Planning, said: "The application site is in a very accessible location. The A and the Edinburgh City Bypassconverge nearby to offer excellent levels of road access from a large surrounding catchment. The site can also be accessed via public transport."It added: "Signicant increases in population and death are projected for East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh over the next  years, which will materially increase the demand for cremation services."Also highlighted were the supposed economic benefits:The planning statement concluded: "Westerleigh have undertaken a comprehensive public consultation exercise in advance of submitting the planning application, including meetings with the Old Craighall Residents Association and Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council."There were no specic objections to the proposals, although understandably the residents of Old Craighall were keen to minimise any perceived negative impacts of the crematorium. Westerleigh have tried to respond to these points where possible."Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, said: "An expanding population and a growing elderly community mean facilities are under increasing pressure."Crematoria are things we sometimes prefer to avoid discussing but theyre essential and delays in accessing them can be distressing."Whether this site or development is appropriate is for planning officers and the planning council to decide but theres a growing need for one somewhere local."

title: tesco-trial-new-service-help-make-life-easier-customers
story: The supermarket chain is launching a new rapid delivery service which will mean it can deliver groceries to customers within an hour.The retail giant is initially trialling the Whoosh delivery service at one store and will then assess potential opportunities to expand the model.It said the one-hour service will be available for customers in selected postcodes around its Wolverhampton Willenhall Express store.The supermarket chain has seen soaring online growth during the pandemic but has so far refrained from following rivals into the on-demand grocery space.Sainsburyrsquos operates its own Chop Chop rapid delivery business, as well as services through Deliveroo and Uber Eats.Meanwhile, Waitrose recently scrapped its own Zoom rapid delivery business in favour of expanding its tie-up with Deliveroo.A raft of major grocery retailers, including Morrisons, Aldi and the Co-op, also use delivery operators such as Deliveroo and Uber Eats to reach customers.Tesco said customers will now be able to order on-demand via its app or Tesco, with products delivered by bike, moped or car, with a pound delivery fee.Chris Poad, online managing director at Tesco, said: ldquoCustomers are telling us that they would welcome the addition of a -minute delivery to their door option as part of our online grocery service.ldquoWersquoll use the pilot to understand how Whoosh could work best for both our customers and our colleagues.

title: dunbar-mums-super-effort-get-set-marathon-relay-run-groups-helped
story: Seven mums ndash and a dad ndash will cover a total of  miles this weekend in aid of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland and Kindred.The parents met through ante-natal classes in Dunbar and are taking part in the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, held virtually due to coronavirus restrictions.Lisa Kitson, Libi Newell, Charlie Hardy and Ky Normand will form the lsquoSuper Mumsrsquo, with Catherine Devereux, Laura Bell, Sarah Callow and Jonathan Newell as the lsquoWonder Womenrsquo, with both teams taking part in the relay event.And another member of the ante-natal classes ndash Caroline Nelson ndash is providing the costumes for the runners, to ensure they look super as they complete the challenge.For Caroline, Catherine and Laura, the causes are close to their hearts. Carolinersquos son Harris and Laurarsquos son Sandy were both born with cerebral palsy, while Catherinersquos daughter Sophie has Downrsquos syndrome.Catherine, , said the two charities had both provided support.She said: ldquoOnce I was able to start looking into things, Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland were just able to provide me a lot of information, a lot of support and a lot of reassurance ndash just simply knowing they were on the end of a phoneI had any queries, be it what I need to be thinking about medically, what appointment we might be thinking or approaching coming up.It was through Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland that Catherine, who works in events, was pointed in the direction of Kindred, which supports parents of children with complex needs with advocacy, information and emotional support.Catherine added: ldquoI have been able to benefit from their counselling services, which have been a great help to me, as well as Laura.The mums all met through ante-natal classes held in Dunbar Medical Centre in the autumn of .Since their babies were born, each has kept in touch.Catherine said: ldquoWe were encouraged at the classes to share numbers and make our WhatsApp group, which has kept going since our children were born and they are now two to two-and-a-half.Together, the mums, who all live in Dunbar or previously lived in the town, are taking on the running challenge, with each lacing up their running shoes ndash and donning their costumes, with Jonathan vowing to pull on a skirtthey reach their fundraising target ndash to run four, six or eight miles.Catherine told the Courier running had proven beneficial not just physically but mentally as well.She said: ldquoI actually started doing Couch to k when my daughter was about eight weeks old.ldquoI had run before but had quite a long break from it.ldquoIt was quite a good thing for me to latch onto and I really love to run with some people as well because I had been doing it largely on my own. It is incredibly beneficial not just physically but mentally.Eddie McConnell, chief executive of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland, wished the runners well.He said: ldquoWe are so grateful to the Dunbar Super Mums and Dunbar Wonder Women for choosing to support Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland.ldquoThe Edinburgh Marathon Relay is a huge challenge to undertake and their commitment in taking on this challenge to support our charity means a great deal to us.ldquoTheir fabulous support and the funds they have raised will help us continue to support families and people with Downrsquos syndrome reach their fullest potential.A spokeswoman for Kindred also wished each of the runners well.She said: ldquoKindred has a new dedicated four-person office based at the new Royal Hospital for Children and Young People. This is better located for East Lothian families than the old hospital, now many of the childrenrsquos services are in the same building so appointment times can be shorter.ldquoKindredrsquos hospital team offers families, emotional and practical support as well as being able to support them at clinical meetings, to understand complex medical information, so they can advocate on behalf of the family or simply help them best represent their childrsquos needs.To support the mums, go to uk.virginmoneygiving Team DunbarSuperMumsandDunbarWonderWomen

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-saying-first-speech-holyrood
story: Irsquom fortunate to have been selected to speak early in this Parliament and Irsquom sharing the outline of my first speech, becoming your voice at Holyrood today .You expect me to deliver for you and, back in January, I promised that my priority would be protecting residentsrsquo wellbeing on our path through the pandemic recovery. My remarks will be addressing how to protect your services secure investment in existing and new facilities on which you depend and ensure that your longer-term needs are met.I stand by my promises and can report progress: the First Minister already specically identied East Lothian Community Hospital as one that would benefit from new spending on local access to healthcare.Boris Johnsonrsquos hard Brexit is damaging farming and tourism, our local food and drink industry and other businesses. As with the unseasonal weather, Brexit is outside our control in East Lothian. However, the SNPrsquos positive and pioneering vision of a green recovery is helping to underpin the countyrsquos sustainability and viability, with the Government delivering  per cent rates relief for retail, leisure, hospitality and aviation for this financial year, along with a rural entrepreneur fund to support businesses.There can be no recovery unless our children and young people flourish. Funds for summer activity schemes will benefit East Lothianrsquos communities locally and pound billion more will directly support teachersrsquo work on closing the deeply rooted attainment gap and the poverty it can perpetuate.Finally, Irsquove set up a new group of South of Scotland SNP MSPs to discuss strategic issues impacting across the region. One of these will be our share of , new houses: I know how strongly you feel about the inter-relationship between affordable housing, appropriate services, public transport and parking.My speech will demonstrate my focus on the Covid recovery in East Lothian, ensuring the county comes out of the pandemic with stronger public services and we can all look forward to a bright future.

title: musselburgh-north-berwick-swimming-pools-close-maintenance-work-completed
story: enjoyleisure welcomed back customers to North Berwick and Musselburgh swimming pools on May , following months of closure due to both the ongoing works and lockdown.The pools were both modernised with new floating floors and booms installed.When the facilities reopened, a maximum depth of . metres was in place and customers were told that more work was needed to make the new booms fully operational.The engineering contractors are toto each pool with the necessary components and materials, which have been custom designed and made for enjoyleisure, and complete the installation.In order to complete the works, specialist sub-contractor ing teams are also scheduled to be in each pool. As a result, both the North Berwick and Musselburgh venues will need to temporarily close.Musselburghs swimming pool will be closed between June  and , while in North Berwick the pool will be closed between June  and . The other facilities in each building will still be available.All of the other pools in East Lothian ndash in Dunbar, Haddington, Tranent and Prestonpans ndash will be open and available for use.Once the boom is fully operational, enjoyleisure will be able to provide iable pool depths for classes and swimming lessons, reinstate family tanks and increase the depth of the pool to provide access to the ing blocks during club sessions.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure chief executive, said: ldquoWe would like to once again express our sincere thanks for our customers patience and understanding during the upgrade of the pool facilities at Musselburgh and North Berwick.ldquoWe fully appreciate that a further interruption of swimming pool access will cause some frustration for our customers.ldquoHowever, both our maintenance partners, East Lothian Council and the engineering contractors are confident this final stage will resolve our outstanding snagging issues.ldquoI sincerely apologise for any disappointment and inconvenience caused.

title: nicola-sturgeons-scotland-lockdown-update-need-know
story: Speaking during a lunchtime Covid briefing in Edinburgh, the First Minister confirmed thatcase numbers in the city are ldquouncomfortably high, but thereare signs both positive tests and the rate of people in hospital with the virus are stabilising.She also outlined plans to announcefurther easing of restrictions across the rest of the country.Here, we outline the key points from her briefing.Glasgow will remain in under strict Covid restrictions as the First Minister said it would be premature to move out of the current level immediately.She said a decision would be made by Wednesday at the latest on whether the city can move to Level  next Saturday.She said: ldquoThe view of the national incident management team is two-fold. Firstly, that it would be premature to move Glasgow out of Level  immediately this week while the situation remains so fragile.Photograph by Colin Mearns April " alt"East Lothian Courier: Shoppers on Buchanan Street, Glasgow today, Monday th April. Shops, cafes, pubs, hospitality venues, gyms and museums opened today due to the easing of lockdown restrictions.Photograph by Colin Mearns April " class"editor-image"ldquoHowever, and secondly,incidence continues to stabilise and assuming levels of hospitalisation remain reasonably stable, the incident management team has made clear to me that they would support a move to Level  from the end of next week.She added: ldquoMy message to the people of Glasgow is donrsquot lose heart. On the contrary, take heart from the progress that we are seeing.ldquoI live in Glasgow so I know how hard this is from my own personal le, but please continue to help with all of the public health efforts that are in place becausewe continue to do this then we will make that move down from Level  to Level , and then after that hopefully get back on track and down the levels further.Ms Sturgeon also said that she will confirm on Tuesdaythe country as a whole can move to Level  as planned on June .Under these restrictions, up tosix people from three households will be able to socialise indoors, and eight people from three households canmeet up in hospitality venues like pubs and restaurants.Indoor hospitality will also be able to operate until pm for both food and alcohol.The latest figures for Scotland show two coronavirus deaths and  cases in the past  hours.It means the death toll under this daily measure ndash of people who first tested positive for the virus within the previous  days ndash stands at ,Of the new cases,  were in Greater Glasgow and Clyde,  in Lothian and  in Lanarkshire.Case numbers, Ms Sturgeon said, are on the rise in Scotland, with Fridayrsquos increase the highest since March  and the R number in Scotland potentially rising as high as ..She said: ldquoA key factor behind the increaseshellip is that the new April-iant, which we think is more transmissible than most other types of the virus, probably now accounts for % or even more of our daily cases.ldquoThe increase in cases so far does seem to be concentrated in younger age groups and this may indicate that vaccination is having a protective effect for older people, which of course we want to see.A new one-shot coronavirus vaccine has been approved for use in the UKI.Approval of the Johnson  Johnson vaccine was announced as the First Minister gave her coronavirus briefing on Friday.The jab is expected to be available in the UK towards the end of this year.The First Minister said: ldquoItrsquos really good news, any new vaccine,itrsquos approved, manufactured and then we get supplies of it, is great.ldquoBut wersquore focused right now on the supplies we actually have and getting them into peoplersquos arms as quickly as possible.National clinical director Professor Jason Leitch said ldquothe more vaccines the better, adding that the Valneva jab is now in phase-three trials which are progressing well.

title: pride-flag-flown-haddington-musselburgh-mark-pride-saltire-event
story: The flying of the rainbow flag coincided with a virtual Pride Saltire East Lothian event held online on Saturday.Pride Saltire, a Pride group for LGBTQ+ people and straight allies in East Lothian, shared videos across its social media s from its  Cockenzie House and Gardens celebration.The group, which lost founder John McMillan and treasurer John Hein last year, honoured both men at the virtual event.A spokesperson for Pride Saltire East Lothian said: ldquoPride is a lot of things to a lot of people, and it was our late founder Johnrsquos goal to allow the people of East Lothian to experience all of them.ldquoWe are proud to continue his legacy by creating a space for LGBTQ+ people across the council and an event that allows a connection between all generations of residents, evenit is, for now, a virtual one.The group hopes it can celebrate Pride Saltire Festival in person next year.Councillor John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, was thanked by the group for agreeing to fly the Pride flag over the two buildings on Saturday.Mr McMillan said he was delighted and proud that East Lothian Council was flying the rainbow flag.He added: ldquoWhile it is unfortunate that Pride Saltire are unable to hold the usual events due to the pandemic, it remains important to celebrate ersity within East Lothian and further afield, recognising and valuing the contribution made by the LGBTQ community.ldquoIt reinforces the message that we want everyone in East Lothian to know that they are welcome and equal citizens.The group also thanked fellow Haddington and Lammermuir councillor Shamin Akhtar.She said: ldquoThis is a fitting tribute for John, who did so much to promote Pride Saltire in East Lothian. Irsquom delighted that the online event took place over the weekend. It was a privilege to have had the opportunity to work with him and without a doubt he has left behind a legacy for us to continue supporting.Pride Scotland hopes to reconnect with the LGBTQ+ community and its allies in East Lothian for Pride Month in June.

title: we-lost-dad-cant-mum-yet-p-k-thinks-can-drive-269-miles-babysitter-glasgow-reacts-dominic-cummings
story: The negative Glaswegian term has been applied by several readers to the Prime Ministerrsquos aide who travelled miles to County Durham in March to self-isolate with his family ndash apparently because he feared that he and his we would be left unable to care for their sonhe became incapacitated with Covid-.He travelled despite official guidelines warning against long-distance journeys.We asked our readers on Facebook what they thought of his behaviour and they gave us typical Glaswegian responses in their droves.Peter Baldwin said: ldquoHersquos a bawbag, while Pauline Stewart, Lynne Weir and Suzy Cullen shared the sentiments.lsquoFannyrsquo and right lsquofannyrsquo were some of the other terms applied to the situation which has angered the nation.Cameron Erroch also accused him of lsquonot giving a f**krsquo.While Maureeen McDade did not mince her words with, lsquoan utterly sleekit cretinrsquo.Here is what  our readers had to say.Maureen Smith said: ldquoThe man was under tremendous pressure. He was helping lead the Covid response. He had thousands of peoplesrsquo lives in his hand. He was also dealing with a sick we and a child. He had to be available. He took them to be cared for then he got ill.ldquoSurely we are big enough to realise that exceptions need to be made for the man who had the b***s to shoulder the responsibility which millions would run from.ldquoGive the guy a break and donrsquot harasses him when he has his wee boy there!Liz Cassidy said: ldquoHe should have stayed home with his we and child. Like the rest of us. title: south-devon-classic-english-beach-destination-full-new-discoveries
story: As my feet weigh down on the pedals and my legs start to burn, I activate turbo mode and battery power aids my climb to the top of the hill. Im on an electric bike and that bead slipping down my cheek is most certainly rain ndash even on the steepest of South Devon hills, Ive barely broken a sweat.Its my second morning in the South Hams region of Devon, located between Torbay and Plymouth and bordering the Dartmoor National Park to the north. Its an all-day drive from Scotland down the M but worth it when you get there, especiallyyou break your journey on the way down and back. There are flights from Glasgow and Edinburgh to Exeter and the train is always an option.Its an area with a strong rural and maritime heritage, where sandy beaches rub up against rich coastal grasslands. And its so pretty, its a designated Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty .Naturally beautul it may be, but exploring on two wheels has largely lacked appeal to the average South Devon visitor, due to the relentless and often steep hills. Thankfully, e-Xplore Devonhave made cycling here more accessible .There are suggested cycling routes on the e-Xplore website, and the -mile Beach Circuit is a delicious amble along coastal roads and through quaint villages. I dismount in the tiny hamlet of Thurlestone and admire its th century thatched roofs and its glorious bay , before continuing to Bolberry Down, a long stretch of rugged coastline.The route continues east and I refuel at The Winking Prawn , a family-run seafood restaurant on Salcombe North Sands beach. Beer fans should order the aptly named Prawn Juice, which is brewed in partnership with the South Hams Brewery.I continue on my cycle and initiate turbo mode, mainly because Im full of garlic prawns and dont fancy a stitch. The route flanks the Salcombe estuary ndash its vibrant blue waters punctuated with small white sailing boats ndash before turning back inland. I finish back at the e-Xplore showroom in Kingsdown and space permitting, you can leave your car there whilst you cycle. The crew at e-Xplore can also drop your bike directly to your accommodation.The rainy weather and long cycle have me craving some home comforts, so I head back to my rustic but extremely cosy shepherds hut. Located at the Salcombe Shepherds Hutsare an excellent choiceyou want a slightly more luxurious camping experience. The four huts are handcrafted using local and sustainable wood, and each includes a log burner , and a fully-equipped kitchen.Im in the Foxes Den which has an en-suite toilet , a comfy double bed , and a small leather couch. I enjoy my morning coffee at the picnic table with its views of the Kingsbridge Estuary and flocks of sheep grazing in the surrounding fields.The next morning Im zipping along country roads to Bigbury-on-Sea, where Im booked in for a surfing lesson with Discovery Surf School . All equipment is provided and Im thankful for a super-thick wetsuit, as the temperature is barely hitting double digits.We start on the beach as Matt, our instructor, guides us through the basics. Were soon in the water and Matts constant encouragement fills us with enthusiasm and motivation, even after numerous wipeouts. Slowly but surely we start to stand, unsteady but feeling accomplished. There are just three of us in my group, but the maximum size is six, so expect lots of useful feedback .Catching tiny waves makes me hungry and I drive the  minutes to Hope Cove, an old fishing village with two sheltered beaches . I settle in at the Lobster Pod Bistrowhich youll find perched on the hillside above Harbour Beach. I gorge on the Seafood Platter, which includes todays catch , alongside potted crab, prawns and a selection of salads.Visitors can sit on outdoor benches or self-contained podsand all have views of the ocean and the grassy Bolt Tail headland . I spend the next hour marvelling over the view. The sun has made an appearance and Im lapping it up with a pint of Salcombe Pale Ale .The small town of Salcombe is one of South Devons most popular , and its independent shops, award-winning restaurants and waterside cafes make it worth a day or two of exploring.Parking can be hectic, so leave the car at your shepherds hut and jump on the number  Tally Ho! bus from Yarde Gate Nursery . Alternatively, you can take the scenic, but extremely hilly, -minute walk into town via the village of Batson.Gin fans should visit the Salcombe Distilling Co. , located on Island Street. Every bottle of Salcombe Gin is distilled here using a single copper still . Tasting sessions include a tour and lots of samples .The distillery also runs a Gin School, which allows visitors to create their own bespoke gin recipe. Youll take charge of a miniature copper under the watchful eye of an expert distiller, who will guide you through the process of choosing botanicals and naming your unique creation. Take your bottle home or enjoy it at the waterside Distillery Bar .Along the street from the distillery, youll find the Salcombe Dairy , which has been churning ice cream for over  years. Over half a million litres of the stuff is pasteurised, churned and packaged each year beneath their shop on Island Street, and theyve recently started making bean to bar chocolate as well. Must-try ice cream flavours include Honeycomband Rum and Raisin .My final evening is spent at waterside restaurant Dick and Wills . Its April and UK government guidelines mean were sitting outside in the freezing wind, but luckily the team are on hand with heaters. The salad from my Asian chilli beef starter gets blown into the estuary, but my main course, a Prime Devonshire steak burger topped with vintage cheddar and a side of chips, proves to be a sturdier and equally delicious option.The rain arrives, but Ive learnt to embrace it this time, because its not a British trip to the seaside without a healthy serving of wind, rain and, well, soggy chips.For details of places to stay, visit or experience in and around Salcombe, visit salcombeinformation.

title: agenda-smooth-return-work-depends-handling-change
story: HYBRID working, where people split time between home and office, is the consequence of a year of novel change in the workplace and looks set to stay. But even as businesses contemplate reopening they must remember that change is unsettling and ato "normal" may feel anything but to employees.Throughout lockdown, we carried out surveys to gauge how clients saw their businesses changing as restrictions tightened. And now, as they ease, many businesses acknowledge that office le will undergo signicant change.Accommodating flexible working means some fundamental aspects might be lost and others added. Hygiene stations and "Zoom spaces" are set to become part of office design, but the days of personal desks for every employee are numbered. And while this is a logical approach to flexible working, the wise business will bring their employees with them on the change journey, before implementing it.Physical space has to support, and be aligned with, new working practices, rather than the other way round. Whether existing space is reconfigured or new offices acquired, it is vital to engage with employees on how best to use the new space to reduce old working practices or workarounds creeping back in.We love our own desks, but our experience is that inidual desk "ownership" leads to a lot of empty desks. The loss of a space to call your own can be unsettling for iniduals, no matter how logical it might be for the business as a whole. Thought and consultation is needed to make "hot-desking" accepted. Some solutions might include personal storage or locker spaces, appropriate portable technology and providing smaller, more flexible private spaces where telephone calls or remote meetings can take place without disruption.Numerous figures have been reported with regards to future space requirementand some organisations have declared the end of the office altogether, stating that their people can work from home indefinitely. Time will tell what the actual change will be.One thing cannot be denied. People want to get back to their offices primarily to interact once more with their colleagues. The informal knowledge-sharing that comes from everyone sharing a workspace cannot be replicated through remote links alone. The sense of belonging that comes from feeling part of something bigger, and an understanding of a business culture and ethos relies on observation and interaction. This is especially true for new starts and junior staff.Physical workspace changes, which might be cost-saving can have other costs in terms of workplace happiness and productivity. So as workplaces open, the transition will ultimately be so much better for those companies that make spatial design decisions that support how their employees want to work, bring staff into the change process and not impose it upon them.Phil Muir is Group Director Consultancy and Design, SPACE

title: mark-smith-cant-scottish-men-admit-kilt-really
story: As for how a traditional kilt is actually made, I saw the process for myself when I visited Kinloch Anderson in Leith. The kilt is made from one eight-yard stretch of material and the skill is chalking it so you know exactly where to put the pleats. The whole thing takes a skilled person about eight hours at least.The problem ndash and itrsquos the same with sporrans ndash is there are lots of cheap imports around, which has put the traditional craft under pressure. Kilt making by hand has now been added to the endangered list kept by the Heritage Crafts Association along with the likes of arrowsmithing, flintknapping, and lorinery. What it means is these wonderful traditions could disappear altogether.:Cummings paints surreal picture of goings-on at dysal Number  ndash Westminster sketchIn some ways though, it does seem strange that the threat to traditional kilt-making should come up now. The kilt has never been so ubiquitous, but maybe a lot of men think the lighter, cheaper kilt is easier to wear and lug about. The cost of a hand-made kilt can also be daunting ndash these days, you can easily pay more than pound,.The other problem with kilts is that,you do get one, it comes with a lot of baggage and attitude, some of which is a load of rubbish. For many, the kilt is the standardised vision of Scotland, but they werenrsquot always so common. My parents married in the s and it didnrsquot even cross my fatherrsquos mind to wear a kilt. I also spoke to the historian Patrick Watt about tartan and his experience was similar. Dr Watt, who was curator of modern history at the National Museum of Scotland, told me his dad did wear a kilt at his wedding in  but people asked what he was doing. ldquoLots of people wear kilts now, he said, ldquobut itrsquos a recent thing ndash in the last  years.No doubt, some of this recent enthusiasm for kilts has something to do with the recent enthusiasm for independence, the idea being that kilts are a link to national identity, rebellion or a form of modern-day Jacobitism. But all Irsquod say to that is: check your history. It may not be true, as some people think, that Highland dress was invented by Walter Scott, but the modern romantic image was popularised and spread by Queen Victoria. And check out this fact: at Culloden, there were kilted solders on both sides.Read more:Rosemary Goring: Battle royal looms as William and Kate deployed to bolster the UnionThe idea of clan tartans, which is also associated with kilts, is a modern obsession too, and an irritating one. Traditionally, people mixed and matched tartans, but now therersquos an idea that you should wear your clan tartan and,you donrsquot, a bumptious bore will tell you why you should. But why does the kilt have to be associated with ldquorules and cultural snobbery  Better to do your own thing .Finally, therersquos one other thing we should talk about, and itrsquos an issue most men are reluctant to discuss: sex and gender. I was at a ceilidh a while ago and the subject of men dressing ldquoas women came up, with most of the guys saying they were uncomfortable with the idea. I pointed out they were expressing this opinion while wearing skirts, to which their response was ldquothese arenrsquot skirts, these are kilts!That says it all, doesnrsquot it  We live in a society that says certain clothes are for women and certain clothes are for men many men also believe skirts are ldquowrong and kilts are ldquoright. But how many men are hiding their true feelings  How many men would like to try ldquowomenrsquos clothes  And how many of them are secretly doing it when they put on their kilts Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-great-scottish-sporting-achievement-sidelined-english-centric-news-values
story: The Prestonpans light-welterweight had gone into his unication fight against Joseacute Ramiacuterez with two of the four world titles to his name, on a par with Watford-born heavyweight Anthony Joshua, but was fighting to become the first British boxer to become holder of the quartet of titles in the "four belt era".It was curious enough that the Taylor Ramiacuterez contest was not covered live by any of the UKs main pay-per-view channels such as Sky or BT Sport ndash it was eventually streamed live on the specialist boxing  FITE TV for a one-off payment of pound ndash but the ing Scottish heros homecoming failed to make the cut on any on the main UK-wide news channels.Rather, on the day of Taylorsto the UK from Las Vegas ndash passing through London Heathrow en route to Edinburgh ndash the main news channels deployed their esteemed sports editorsto the announcement of Gareth Southgates provisional squad for the delayed Euro , Englands opening fixture still a full three weeks away, his final -man squad still a week from being finalised.Whilst appreciating the numbers game between Scotland and England and the juxtaposition in popularity between football and boxing, surely Taylors unprecedented actual achievement should have carried signicantly greater editorial weight ahead of a provisional squad pre-announcement for one team taking part in an event that will not reach its denouement for almost two months Given such England-centric prejudice in drawing-up daily national news agendas, is it little wonder that we Scots ndash and incidentally Welsh and Northern Irish too ndash feel so undervalued and alienated, when our ground-breaking national achievements are at best sidelined and all too often ignored in favour of what are, in reality, second rate ndash but English ndash stories Mike Wilson, Longniddry.YES, ISRAEL SHOULD APOLOGISEIN reply to the letter by M Green , yes, Israel should apologise. For cynical actions in East Jerusalem that deliberately sought to provoke a reaction from Hamas that would distract attention from Netanyahus dishonesty and illegality. For operating an apartheid state where Arab Israelis do not have the same rights as Jewish Israelis. For turning Gaza into a refugee camp instead of allowing an independent Palestine state to flourish.Israel will never enjoy peace while it continues to oppress Palestinians. I share the view that Hamas are extremist thugs who use civilians as a human shield, but I cant see what Israel is achieving by bombing these innocent people. The US should insist on a two-state solution as a condition of further support for Israel.Sandy Slater, Stirling.TIME TO AIR PRIVATE CONCERNSGUY Stenhouserehashes his opinion that private is good and public is bad in almost all his columns. Reading the same point made week after week, I am tempted to askyou pay him with the same cheque week after week. If not, you should certainly consider it.Irsquod like to ask Mr Stenhouse two questions:Has he ever visited the AE department of a private American hospital where his credit card would be more important than his illness Has he tried comparing the publicly-owned French railways with their privatised British equivalent  A French TGV would take him  miles in less time than a British train for less than half the price.Sam Craig, Glasgow.WHY THE FUSS ABOUT LEAVING SCHOOL ALTHOUGH I am only  years old, the letterfrom Ed Brown complaining that there would be no ldquoreal celebrations for his daughter leaving primary school confirmed once more that the modern world is something completely alien to me.When my friends and I left primary school there were no celebrations, organised or otherwise. Proms were unheard of. We just got on with it. It was no big deal and none of us were any the worse for it.David Clark, Tarbolton.AYE I MIGHT I join David Brown and David Millerin their club for Grumpy Old Men  Having squirmed when I read Nicola Loves columnand her statement that a quick call had secured "my partner and I" vaccination appointments, I concluded that the blame must lie squarely at the door of Oscar Hammerstein II for failing to correctly name his musical The King and Me.Eric Begbie, Stirling.A MUTE POINTI WAS shocked to learn that comedian Les Dennis is now involved in an opera production by Gilbert and Sullivan . I am not shocked by the radical change of direction in his career but by the description of the work of Gilbert and Sullivan as "opera".I am with the late Italian conductor Arturo Toscanini  per cent when he said that Italian opera should be sung in Italian. French opera in French, German opera in German and English opera should not be sung at all.Poor Verdi, Bizet and Wagner will all be rolling over in their graves.Tina Oakes, Stonehaven.

story: But itrsquos a sandwich The culinary offering, due to debut on June , has been dubbed ldquoone of the most expensive sandwiches in the world and to be fair, itrsquos not just a slather of jam or some ham squashed between some pan loaf.So whatrsquos in it then It features salami, rosemary ham, provolone cheese, sun-dried tomato spread on toasted focaccia with marinara dipping sauce and arugula salad on the side and the sandwich is actually supersized - Disney say it is meant to be shared between six to eight people.If you donrsquot want to share A regular-sized version retails at ., which is still more than you might pay for anything in the sandwich bracket.Itrsquos super-sized, but its inspired by Ant-Man The "Quantum-sized Pym-ini" sandwich will retail at the Pym Test Kitchen, which takes its name from the "pym particles" used for the size-altering physics referenced in the Ant-Man movies, starring Paul Rudd. The restaurant itself - on the Calornia theme parkrsquos new "Avengers Campus - will serve dishes that have fun with proportions, including the ldquoCaesar Salad and Colossal Crouton, a salad that comes with just one giant crouton, and the ldquoImpossible Spoonful - a huge meatball on a supersized metal spoon.Itrsquos not the most expensive thing on the Disney menu At the resortrsquos Steakhouse  restaurant inside the Disneyland Hotel, diners can splash out on a -ounce  Porterhouse steak, while at Walt Disney World in Florida, the Takumi-Tei restaurant in the Japan pavilion at the EPCOT theme park has ious menu items that pass , including a Wagyu tenderloin and a omakase sushi service.If you have money to burn There are plenty of options, including dining at Disneylandrsquos  Royal, a VIP eatery housed in what was supposed to be Walt Disneyrsquos plush family residence, although he died before it was completed. The experience - for up to  guests - reportedly costs ,, and features personal chefs, butlers and valets and ldquoan evening of tantalising and succulent flavours, as well as park tickets.You can still splash even more cash than this, though Club  is a Disney private dining club for high rollers. Members pay around , for an initiation fee and around , to retain their membership.As for sandwicheshellipAccording to Guinness World Records, the most expensive sandwich available commercially is the "Quintessential Grilled Cheese" which sells for  at Serendipity  in New York. The pricey sarnie is served on two pieces of French Pullman champagne bread which is made with Dom Perignon champagne and edible gold flakes, with white truffle butter and the very rare Caciocavallo Podolico cheese. The sandwich is served with South African Lobster Tomato Bisque as a dipping sauce.

title: watch-nicola-sturgeons-glasgow-covid-briefing-expected
story: The First Minister is expected todeliver a Covid- briefing today where she will set out the plans for Scotlands largest city, which has spent  under tight rules designed to curb the virus.Ms Sturgeon has said there are "reasons to be optimistic" about the situation in the city, but business owners have saidthey need clarity on when they can fully reopen.:Glasgow restrictions could be lted on watch and wait basisGlasgow is the only part of Scotland to remain in level three restrictions.Opposition parties have called for urgent action to get Glasgow back on a level footing with the rest of the country as quickly as possible.This morning,Murdo Fraser, Scottish Conservative Covid- recovery spokesman, saidthe latest data shows infections are still high then a ldquomore targeted approach was needed.The first minister is expected to announce the result of a review of restrictions in a Covid- briefing at :. This will be screened on the Scottish Governments Facebook page and through Twitter, and on BBC Scotland.Ms Sturgeon told MSPs on Thursday that she wants to get the city back on track "as quickly as possible, but thats got to be done responsibly and safely".But she said she would continue to make "careful, cautious" decisions on the path back to normality.:Nicola Sturgeon blames Boris Johnsons bad decisions for loss of le from CovidThe First Minister said: "I know how dficult it is for residents and businesses across Glasgow, but I also know how dangerous it would bewe eased restrictions too quickly and allowed a new iant of this virus, that we know is spreading perhaps even more quickly than the iant at the start of the year, to take a grip again."Thats why there are the public health interventions under way across Glasgow right now."I said earlier in the week we see cautious signs for optimism that that is working, and we will continue to monitor that very carefully."

title: covid-19-glasgow-downgraded-level-2-restrictions
story: The First Ministersaid infections hadrisen by % in the city in the past seven days,from  cases per , peopleto witha slight increase in the .% test positivity rate.However, shesaid there were early signs that the escalation of public health measuresincluding an acceleration of vaccinationswas "starting to improve the situation".New cases insouth side trouble spots have fallen in recent days, she said and infections across the city and hospital admissionshave stabilised while ICU numbers remain low.Glasgow will move to Level  from next Saturdayhospital and infection case numbers continue to stabilise or drop and the position will be confirmed "no later than Wednesday".: First Minister warns Glasgow residents not to copy Green party boozingNicola Sturgeon said she "didnt have to imagine" how tough it was for the people ofGlasgow to remain in Level  restrictions because she isaresident herself.They mean people are not allowed to meet in each others homes, and pubs and restaurants are not able to sell alcohol indoors.She said: "None of this is fairbut what would be unfair isI took reckless decisions."The hope is that we are seeing signs of the situation in Glasgow stabilising and improving."Case levels in Glasgow are uncomfortably high but there are signs of progress.: Glasgow to offer drop-in slots for Covid vaccinations to catch missed over-s"So the view of the National Incident Management Team is that it would be premature to move Glasgow out of Level  immediately this week while the situation remains so fragile."However,incidence continues to stabilise, and assuming levels of hospitalisation remain reasonably stable, they will support a move to Level  from the end of next week."I want to be clear that we do need to see these positive signs continuing to make that a reality."Mymessage to the people of Glasgow is, donrsquot lose heart. I live in the city, so I know how hard this is."But please, continue to help with all of the public health efforts that are in place. If we continue to do that, we will move out of Level  quickly."There were  positive cases across Scotland - the largest number reported since May . Of those, were reportedin the NHS Greater Glasgow area, in Lothian and in Lanarkshire. Nicola Sturgeon said the Rnumber could now be as high as ., which is being signantly driven by Glasgow.Thetotal number of cases across Scotland is now, and there are people in hospital, sevenmore than yesterday with sixin intensive care, twomore than yesterday. Two deaths were reported  hours bringing the total number to ,.A total of , people have received first dose of vaccinations, anincrease of , since yesterday with ,  receiving asecond dose."We continue to make really good progress," said the First Minister."We do think vaccinations is changing the impact the virus has, which gives us grounds for real hope." However, she said our understanding of the extent to which vaccines are breaking or weakening the link between rising case numbers and serious illness, particularly related to the Indian iant,is "not complete".She urged the public, particularly those in Glasgow, to attendvaccination appointments stressing that full immunity was dependent on second doses and said the Government was working to try to alleviate problems that have led to higher non attendance rates.: Conservatives call for local lockdowns targeted testing in Glasgow"This is never going to be a perfect decision. We try to leave it as late as possible to take advantage of the most up-to-date data."The best thing is to do what we are all doing and get this under control so that hopefully the news can be better by next week."Askedshe would consider confining tougherrestrictions tothe south ofGlasgow, the First Minister said it would be problematic to "sub-ide" the city and to enforce that in any kind of meaningful way."We hope that in the not too distant future the whole city can be brought down to Level . Its not just the south side that has cases."The First Minister said it would not be an unreasonably assumption that Glasgow could remain inLevel  for longer than other local authorities because of the higher number of cases.Professor Jason Leitch, National Clinical Director, said the hardest part of the Glasgow restrictions was "keeping families apart" with the effect on hospitality second to that.The Indian iant now counts for % of new cases in Scotland but appears to be concentrated in younger people. Mr Leitch said more iants were inevitable and said there was a much longer term decision to be made about future vaccination strategy and whether it will involve children.He said there were ethical decisions why it might not be appropriate to vaccinate children and said it was possible they could be focussed on the over-s in the longer term.Areas with thehighest rates in Glasgow includeIbrox,Pollokshields East andDumbreck. Infections are now said to be rising in areas of Lanarkshire includingBellshill, Cambuslang, East Kilbride and Hamilton.: Business leaders describe Glasgow restrictions decision as "galling"There has been a rapid acceleration of vaccinations in the south side of the city, where cases have spiked, with younger people also fast tracked and there are plans to set up drop-in sessions at The Hydro, starting this weekend, tocatch over s who have missed appointments.Additional funding is to be made available to Glasgow City Council to provide additional support for businesses in hospitality and leisure in Glasgow, with grants ranging from pound to pound per week.Other areas of concern across Scotland including Renfrewshire, East Renfrewshire and Clackmannanshire are continuing to be monitored.Mainland Scotland is currently due to move from Level  to Level  on June .The First Minister said she is planning to confirm on Tuesday to Parliament whether that move will take place.

title: issue-day-french-films-cant-kick-habit
story: How so A new survey, conducted to mark World Tobacco Day on Monday, reveals that French cinema is still addicted to cigarettes, with more than  per cent of movies made from  to  featuring either a character smoking, the presence of cigarettes or ashtrays or a character talking about smoking.Itrsquos big advertising for tobacco then According to the French League Against Cancer - who commissioned the Ipsos research - it equates to . minutes of screen time on average per movie, giving tobacco an exposure equivalent to six advertising spots. A spokesman said: ldquoTobacco is quasi-ubiquitous in French films. Between  and , .% of films include at least one event, one object, or a line related to tobacco.Cest tregraves franccedilais Therersquos no denying that French movie history is littered with cigarettes and form part of an era where smoking was glamourised on screen, with icons such as Brigitte Bardot, Serge Gainsbourg, Catherine Deneuve and Geacuterard Depardieu among those who lit up. The French actor, Jean-Paul Belmondo, spent much of one memorable movie - the  offering ldquoAgrave Bout du Souffle, puffing on a Gauloise - which is one of Francersquos most iconic cigarettes.Of course, itrsquos not just French films Smoking is woven through cinema history, with iconic scenes in movies ranging from Pulp Fiction to Basic Instinct. The first time we met  in Dr No, Sean Connery uttered his iconic line, ldquoBond, James Bond while lighting up, with cigarettes forming part of the character journeys in films such as The Graduate and Grease, to demonstrate the transformation of Dustin Hoffmanrsquos Ben and Olivia Newton-Johnrsquos Sandy respectively.James Dean The American icon was rarely seen without a cigarette and smoking on screen was part of the package in movies such as Rebel Without a Cause, while Audrey Hepburnrsquos cigarette was an accessory in Breakfast at Tfanyrsquos.Smoking is on the rise in France The movie survey came just days after Francersquos health authority, Sante Public, reported that  marked the end of a years-long downward trend in smoking in the country. The organisation blamed a ldquosocial crisis context and the influence of Covid-, with more lower-income people smoking than in  and fewer smokers trying to quit. They specically found that among current smokers, .% reported an increase in their tobacco consumption.Anti-smoking campaigners are concerned The Leaguersquos president, Axel Kahan, said, ldquoThe League vigorously denounces the glamorising of smoking in French films over the past  years, and criticised ldquocampaigns targeting young people, that are as aggressive as they are insidious.However Past efforts to encourage French cinema directors to kick the habit on screen sparked complaints from the arts establishment, with some questioning whether foreign films would also be subjected to a ban - including James Bond. French philosopher and commentator, Raphaeumll Enthoven, said in  that it was ldquocensorship under the pretext of public health, adding, ldquoInjecting morality into the lsquoseventh artrsquo [cinema] is like pouring cola into a Chacircteau Lafite, one of Francersquos most prestigious wines.

title: brian-taylor-nicola-sturgeon-want-pact-greens-meets-eye
story: Sometimes, as with his own West Lothian Question, he would opt for attrition, pursuing Ministers endlessly.However, I preferred his approach succinct. Responding to an initial written question, a Minister would read out a turgid civil service response, then subside gratefully, hoping for a y supplementary to catch his breath.Up from the Labour side would bound Tam, to declare in his sonorous Etonian tones: ldquoHow much  Or, even better: ldquoWhy  Cue startled Minister.I thought of Tam when I pondered the question of a putative co-operation deal between the SNP Scottish Government and the Greens. Recalling my journalistic coaching, I asked: ldquoWho, what, when, where, why :Now Swinney has moved on, how will we sort out Scotlandrsquos struggling schools We know who: two parties, of dferent stature, supporting independence with ying degrees of fervour.We know what: a co-operation agreement short of full coalition. Eventually, there might be Green Ministers. For now, too soon.More to the point, the Greens stress they would reserve the right to dissent on certain specied issues. Which means no collective governmental responsibility. Which means no Ministers, for now.When  The talks are said to be at an early stage with months of discussion to come. Where  Holyrood.The big question, though, is why. One observer tells me that the Green co-leaders, Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater, seemed faintly taken aback at the initial ldquotalks about talks. Warily and sensibly, they stressed the need to consult colleagues.However, they have agreed to continue negotiating, noting en passant that they have secured concessions in recent Budget deals.There is history here. In , Alex Salmond led a minority administration. He tried to strike a partnership deal with the Liberal Democrats. That fell apart: key LibDems found the SNP and independence fundamentally unpalatable.Mr Salmond then turned to the Green MSPs. All two of them. The leader Robin Harper, with his permanent smile and Dr Who scarf. And Patrick Harvie, an astute politician even then.Again, a full partnership proved impossible, owing to a dispute over transport policy among other issues. A compact was signed to support the election of Mr Salmond as First Minister.That was not really needed: subsequent history proved that the party with the most MSPs would, in practice, be permitted by Parliament to enter office.They said they had been sold short. Mr Swinney was, to put it mildly, less than pleased. That memory no doubt lingers in the mind of the Deputy First Minister as he contemplates the new round of talks.So, again, why  Especially now, when the SNP are just one short of an overall majority in Holyrood.I sought answers from my Herald Podcast  among the number, Kezia Dugdale, who formerly led Labour and now heads the John Smith Centre. She disclosed that she had conducted extensive research, including a phone call to a pal in New Zealand, where there has been cross-party co-operation.She was advised that the Greens there felt they gained clout and influence. Labour leaders felt they gained extra security, including a pact which obviated the need for tense annual Budget talks.:Is independence inevitable or can unionists rescue the realm they cherish The deal has persisted, even though Labour won a majority last year. Some Greens are discontented.Scottish Green sources point to the New Zealand model, stressing the capacity to criticise the administration. They are less enthusiastic about the example of Ireland where some Greens fear their ideology risks being swamped in a compact with centre-right parties.Either way, it is, partly, about money. Nicola Sturgeon and Kate Forbes want to pre-empt the annual agony of Budgetary negotiations by securing potential support in advance.Not an easy sell. SNP Ministers are adamant they will stick to an income tax freeze for the duration of this Parliament. Greens favour a more radical approach to revenue, as they would see it, including a possible wealth taxa way could be found.But compromise could be reached. There will be other obstacles, such as Green opposition to road building. The FM said this week that dualling the A, for example, will not be halted.Then there is the North Sea. The parties dfer over the pace of shting away from oil and gas. With the COP  UN climate conference due in Glasgow, the SNP may be ready to give yet more ground, while protecting north-east jobs.Always, of course, there is independence. Would a compact add more impetus to the case for indyref  Not, I suspect, in terms of influencing the UK Government. But it would perhaps be a reminder of the ersity of support for independence.There is, however, a third motivation, beyond cash and indyref. The SNP have been in power for  years. The previous Holyrood session had a toxic tang: Brexit independence arguments and Nicola Sturgeon gazing fretfully over her shoulder at her ever-present predecessor.I believe the FM wants a fresh approach. Literally, a new politics. Sceptics will say this is purely about presentation. I think it is also strategic. By making a choice, by making a new alliance, Ms Sturgeon hopes to banish staleness from her own party, and simultaneously challenge rivals to refresh.She hopes, in so doing, to isolate the Tories. They respond by warning that the Greens will push her in an anti-business direction.She hopes, also, to challenge Labour, over policy and indyref. Anas Sarwar was, understandably, ill-prepared. His first response was simply to revive an old Labour theme, deriding the recreation of a spending cuts coalition.He will need a new tone, new phrases. However,a deal emerges, he and others will still rightly demand: ldquoWhy  And: ldquoHow much  Tam Dalyell would be proud.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: sturgeons-claim-uk-government-not-engaging-australia-trade-deal-wrong
story: At First Ministerrsquos Questions on Thursday, Nicola Sturgeon said she felt Scotland was being ldquoshut out of a potential deal with Canberra ndash which could grant tarf and quota-free trade.The First Minister went on to claim the deal would be a ldquobetrayal of British farmers, adding that food imports must meet the standards of production in Scotland.But a spokeswoman for the DIT rejected Ms Sturgeonrsquos assertion.ldquoIt is simply wrong to suggest the Government is not engaging on this issue, she said.ldquoEngagement on the UK-Australia FTAis taking place with all parts of the UK at all levels.ldquoTrade ministers have been discussing this with Scottish ministers throughout the process, most recently this week, and will continue to do so as we move forward in the negotiations.ldquoOfficials from the governments of Scotland and Wales and the Northern Ireland Executive receive weekly updates from the negotiation team, on top of being involved in countless hours of technical policy discussions.ldquoAny deal we sign will include protections for the agriculture industry and will not undercut UK farmers or compromise our high standards.The DIT has said there was a meeting with Scottish Government ministers on the deal this week, and all devolved administrations receive weekly updates.But Ms Sturgeon said Scotlandrsquos Rural Affairs Secretary Mairi Gougeon and business minister Ivan McKee used the meeting to voice their concerns over the deal, which they say could be ldquodevastating for the farming sector.The proposed deal has also caused concern with other ministers, with Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove fearing it could fuel support for Scottish and Welsh independence, while Environment Secretary George Eustice has backed the protestations of farmers, who fear the impact any deal may have.

title: brian-taylor-podcast-kezia-dugdale-ross-greer-rona-mackay-andy-maciver-discuss-snp-greens-deal
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced that the Government was discussing a possible cooperation agreement with the Greens earlier this week.The deal could seeGreen MSPs entering the Scottish Government as ministers.Ms Sturgeon referred to the move as"potentially groundbreaking" and stressed "we are setting no limits on our ambition".Speaking exclusively on the latest episode of The Brian Taylor Podcast, Ms Dugdale claimed there were three clear reasons for the agreement.:Nicola Sturgeon in talks with Greens over groundbreaking cooperation dealShe said: "I was baffled by this, I just didnt get it. Why on earth would the SNP want to deal with the Greens, why would they need to "Why would the Greens sign up for that  Whenever you see smaller parties in cooperation agreements they get a kicking in the next election it didnt make sense to me."However, the former Scottish Labour leader believes it boils down to the Budget, New Zealand stylecollective responsibility and "great" PRahead of COP.Ms Dugdale said: "I dont think we can ignore the fact this is going to look very sweet ahead of Cop."She emphasised the importance of the agreement for the SNP is for the budget:"This is about moving away from the Greens influence only being at Budget time because what a cooperation agreementwould doit follows the New Zealand example is say that the Greens cannot vote against the budget."They dont have to vote for it but they cannot vote against it and abstaining is enough for a Budget to pass."The advantage for the Greens is that they can have more than one moment in a political year and they can also spread that influence across a couple of directorates or policy areas that they choose to work on. And I know I am right because Rossgettingreally shty in his seat now.":SNP refuse to back down over income tax in governing talks with GreensScottish Greens MSP Ross Greer responded that he was nodding "enthusiastically" to her argument.Addressing the second reason for the deal, Ms Dugdale added: "People go surely that means the Greens will have to vote for everythingthey sign up in some part."No, in New Zealand collective responsibility only applies to the areas where you agree to cooperate."While she acknowledgedthe public relations aspect of the deal is not the only reason for it she added: "We are ahead of COP. This is great PR. It looks good."Speaking of the deal, Mr Greer said: "Climate is the area which we will be the SNP to move quite signicantly from what their record has been so far."We wouldnt have gotto this stage thoughwe thought there was no chance of them doing that. The early indications are they are willing to move."In the latest episode Brian is joined byformer leader of Scottish Labour Kezia Dugdale, SNP MSP Rona Mackay, Scottish Greens MSP Ross Greer and former Conservative adviser and director of Message Matters Andy Maciver.

title: inadequate-opposition-party-domination
story: The Daily MailJanet Street-Porter said to dismiss Cummings lsquoexplosiversquo testimony as bitter score-settling would be a huge mistake.ldquoHe saw it all at first hand - the U turns, the blind refusal to focus on the impending tragedy, the inability to grasp detail and make tough decisions, she said. ldquoThe obsession with how things would play in the media, the narcissism of a Prime Minister who wants to be loved at all costs.Where was the leadership she asked.ldquoHancock - who Cummings says lied over and over again - strenuously denies the accusations and now said he only promised to start testing them once he actually had the tests, she said. ldquoBut the facts arenrsquot in his favour - senior civil servants, scientists and medical experts all agree - Cummings is only telling us what we always suspected.ldquoWe must get to the bottom of what went wrong and those culpable must be removed from office. If another crisis comes along tomorrow do you really believe the government will be any better prepared The Ross Clark askedthere was any sight more ridiculous than that of Labourrsquos deputy leader Angela Rayner now treating Dominic Cummings as a fountain of wisdom.ldquoThis is a man she spent much of last year ridiculing, telling us we couldnrsquot believe a word he said. Yet suddenly he is a great sage, whose ldquoserious and ldquodevastating revelations about the Governmentrsquos handling of Covid- should be taken at face value, he said.He said it was undeniable that the Government had made mistakes in handling Covid and the greatest was discharging NHS patients into care homes without testing.ldquoHopefully the inquiry will do a better job of exposing bad policy than has Labourrsquos frontbench, members of which have provided little in the way of useful opposition over the past year.Andy Beckett said British politics feels more dominated by one party than at any time since New Labourrsquos peak years almost a quarter of a century ago.ldquoBoris Johnson seems to be leading a breakout from his partyrsquos usual ideological and territorial zones, into a wider political space where a British prime minister can enjoy rare freedom of action and their party can shake off restrictive old associations, he said. ldquo Cummings is not a Tory, and that surely sharpened his select committee testimony this week. His contempt for Hancock, and his comparison of the prime minister to an out-of-control shopping trolley echoed things he had said about other Conservative politicians. Only an overconfident party allows such an outsider to become an insider.ldquoWhen the governmentrsquos Covid bills come due, Johnson will have to do more choosing between interests and policies than he has so far.

title: covid-glasgow-businesses-leaders-say-level-three-decision-galling
story: Liz Cameron OBE, Chief Executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said many were counting on the extra income from the bank holiday weekend, only to see their hopes dashed as Glasgow will remain the only area in Scotland under tougher rules.Nicola Sturgeon has announced there will be no change to the citys coronavirus restrictions as cases are remain"uncomfortably high", although a decision will be made next week when the picture becomes clearer.The level three restrictions mean people are not allowed to meet in each others homes, and pubs and restaurants are not able to sell alcohol indoors.Many Glasgow business owners say they are struggling to survive after spending  days under tough restrictions, and have criticised the Scottish government for not giving them more financial support.Ms Cameron said theere had been "anxious businesses" across Scotland waiting to hear the news, as well as prospective day trippers and tourists.The hospitality trade has had to adaptThe business chief said: "The impact of this extended closure will be even more devastating for crisis hit businesses in Glasgow, as many were looking forward to opening their doors to take advantage of the upcoming bank holiday on Monday.ldquoWe need government at both Holyrood and Westminster to now step in to provide a level of meaningful financial supportwe are to save jobs and livelihoods."Ms Cameron added that there were "glimmers ofhope" offered by the vaccination programme and expanded test and protect effort.:Conservatives call for local lockdowns and targeted testingShe said: "We seem to be going in the right direction as far as the health harms are concerned but the economic harms are just as critical."We hope that the review promised next week will bring a decision to enable Glasgow to move down into Level , allowing businesses to plan ahead and fully welcome consumers and tourists back.Andrew McRae, Federation of Small BusinessesScotland Policy Chair, said: the decision to keep Glasgow in level three was "galling".He said: ldquoGlasgow businesses are getting used to these weekly Friday disappointments. This one is all the more galling because it looks like Monday will see Glasgow basking in the sort of gloriously sunny Bank Holiday that could have helped small hospitality operators recoup some of their losses.ldquoThe First Minister did suggest there might be light at the end of the tunnel next week ndash and breaking the Friday-for-Monday announcement cycle will give business owners a little more notice."Itrsquos very dficult to run a business, or plan your family finances, when you need to tune into the lunchtime news on a Friday to find outyoursquoll be working on the Monday."Mr McRae added: ldquoThe businesses and employees hardest hit by these ongoing restrictions need proper support now. The Glasgow hospitality industry was given two days to scrap their re-opening plans."But even now, after two weeks, we still donrsquot have adequate financial support measures in place. That needs remedied as a matter of urgency.:Glasgow to stay in Level  as Covid cases remain uncomfortably highStephen Montgomery, of the Scottish Hospitality Group said he beleived the restrictions were unnecessary.He said: "All thatrsquos going to happen is people will continue to travel outside Glasgow city centre, further spreading the virus. We already know thatrsquos happening."So,things are really that bad that there needs to be this continued lockdown, then this is a counter-productive move and makes no sense as far as the governmentrsquos policy is concerned."Mr Montgomeryadded: "We firmly believe the approach based on case numbers is largely irrelevant now. Itrsquos admissions and other hospital data that should be used and itrsquos great to see that those are remaining at a very low level."With the vaccine roll-out and all the preventative measures that the government has had us put in place, it should be possible to remove Glasgow from these unfair restrictions now."It is quite staggering to think that the plan for the fan zone at Glasgow Green is in full swing, but here we have a situation where Scottish Government thinks that keeping Glasgow City in level  and throwing hospitality businesses a pitul pound per week is acceptable."

story: AFTER last weekrsquos item on SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford, we bring readers more news on the self-styled ldquohumble crofter. But knowing his democratic tastes, surely a humble community buy-out is only a matter of time.Wowie BowieAberdeenshire Tory MP Andrew Bowie has been naively promoting his outdoor surgeries by plastering social media with pics of himself and a gazebo bearing the slogan ldquoMP on the Green.
